{{About|the English word ''Jew''|the Jewish people|Jews}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Wiktionary|Jew}} {{Jews and Judaism sidebar}} The English term '''''Jew''''' originates in the [[Biblical Hebrew]] word ''Yehudi'', meaning "from the [[Kingdom of Judah]]", or "[[Jew]]". It passed into Greek as ''[[Ioudaios]]'' and Latin as ''Iudaeus'', which evolved into the [[Old French]] ''giu'' after the letter "d" was dropped. A variety of related forms are found in early English from about the year 1000, including ''Iudea'', ''Gyu'', ''Giu'', ''Iuu'', ''Iuw'', and ''Iew'', which eventually developed into the modern word. == Etymology == {{further|Ioudaios}} [[File:John Hyrcanus.jpg|250px|thumb|left|[[Hasmonean]] coin of [[John Hyrcanus]] (134 to 104 BCE) with the inscription ''"Hayehudim"'' (of the [[Jews]]).
'''Obv:''' Double cornucopia.
'''Rev:''' Five lines of ancient Hebrew script; reading ''"Yehochanan Kohen Gadol, Chever Hayehudim"'' (Yehochanan the [[Kohen Gadol|High Priest]], Council of the [[Jews]].]] [[File:Kingdoms of Israel and Judah map 830.svg|thumb|upright|250px|Map of the region in the 9th century BCE]] === ''Yehudi'' in the Hebrew Bible === According to the [[Book of Genesis]], [[Judah (Biblical figure)|Judah]] ({{Hebrew|יְהוּדָה}}, ''Yehudah'') was the name of the fourth son of the patriarch [[Jacob]]. During the Exodus, the name was given to the [[Tribe of Judah]], descended from the patriarch Judah. After the conquest and settlement of the land of [[Canaan]], Judah also referred to the territory allocated to the tribe. After the splitting of the [[Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)|united Kingdom of Israel]], the name was used for the southern [[kingdom of Judah]]. The kingdom now encompassed the tribes of Judah, [[Tribe of Benjamin|Benjamin]] and [[Tribe of Simeon|Simeon]], along with some of the cities of the [[Tribe of Levi|Levites]]. With the destruction of the northern [[kingdom of Israel (Samaria)]], the kingdom of Judah became the sole Jewish state and the term ''y'hudi'' ({{Hebrew|יהודי}}) was applied to all Israelites. When the word makes its first appearance in writing (in the book of Esther) its meaning has already expanded to include converts to the Jewish religion as well as descendants of Israelites. The term ''Yehudi'' ({{Hebrew|יְהוּדִי}}) occurs 74 times in the [[Masoretic text]] of the Hebrew Bible. The plural, ''Yehudim'' ({{Hebrew|הַיְּהוּדִים}}) first appears in {{bibleverse|2|Kings|16:6|HE}} where it refers to a defeat for the Yehudi army or nation, and in {{bibleverse|2|Chronicles|32:18|HE}}, where it refers to the language of the Yehudim ({{Hebrew|יְהוּדִית}}). {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|34:9|HE}} has the earliest singular usage of the word ''Yehudi''. In {{bibleverse||Esther|2:5-6|HE}}, the name "Yehudi" ({{Hebrew|יְהוּדִי}}) has a generic aspect, in this case referring to a man from the [[tribe of Benjamin]]: :"There was a man a ''Yehudi'' (Jewish man) in [[Shushan]] the capital, whose name was [[Mordecai]] the son of Jair the son of [[Shimei]] the son of [[Kish (Bible)|Kish]], a [[Benjamite]]; who had been exiled from [[Jerusalem]] with the exile that was exiled with [[Jeconiah]], king of [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]], which [[Nebuchadnezzar]], king of [[Babylon]], had exiled." The name appears in the Bible as a verb in {{bibleverse||Esther|8:17|HE}} which states: :"Many of the people of the land ''became Yehudim'' (in the generic sense) ({{Hebrew|מִתְיַהֲדִים}}, ''mityahadim'') because the fear of the Yehudim fell on them." In some places in the [[Talmud]] the word ''Israel(ite)'' refers to somebody who is Jewish but does not necessarily practice [[Judaism]] as a [[religion]]: "An Israel(ite) even though he has sinned is still an Israel(ite)" (Tractate ''Sanhedrin'' 44a). More commonly the Talmud uses the term ''Bnei Yisrael'', i.e. "Children of Israel", ("Israel" being the name of the third patriarch [[Jacob]], father of the sons that would form the twelve tribes of Israel, which he was given and took after wrestling with an angel, see [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 32:28-29http://bible.ort.org/books/pentd2.asp?ACTION=displaypage&BOOK=1&CHAPTER=32) to refer to Jews. According to the Talmud then, there is no distinction between "religious Jews" and "secular Jews." In [[modern Hebrew]], the same word is still used to mean both Jews and Judeans ("of Judea"). In [[Arabic]] the terms are ''yahūdī'' (sg.), ''al-yahūd'' (pl.), and بَنُو اِسرَائِيل ''banū isrāʼīl''. The [[Middle Aramaic|Aramaic]] term is ''{{transl|arc|Y'hūdāi}}''. === Development in European languages === [[File:Page from Yiddish-Hebrew-Latin-German dictionary by Elijah Levita.jpg|thumb|250px|A page from [[Elia Levita]]'s [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]]-[[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]-[[Latin language|Latin]]-[[German language|German]] dictionary (16th century) contains a list of nations, including an entry for Jew: {{lang-he|יְהוּדִי}} {{lang-yi|יוּד}} {{lang-de|Jud}} {{lang-la|Iudaeus}}]] The [[Septuagint]] (reputedly a product of [[Hellenistic Judaism|Hellenistic Jewish]] scholarship) and other Greek documents translated {{Hebrew|יְהוּדִי}}, ''Yehudi'' and the [[Middle Aramaic|Aramaic]] ''{{transl|arc|Y'hūdāi}}'' using the [[Koine Greek]] term ''[[Ioudaios]]'' ({{lang-grc-gre|[[Wiktionary:Ἰουδαῖος|Ἰουδαῖος]]}}; pl. {{lang|grc|Ἰουδαῖοι}} ''Ioudaioi''), which had lost the 'h' sound. The [[Medieval Latin|Latin]] term, following the Greek version, is ''Iudaeus'', and from these sources the term passed to other European languages. The [[Old French]] ''giu'', earlier ''juieu'', had [[elision|elided]] (dropped) the letter "d" from the Latin ''Iudaeus''. The [[Middle English]] word ''Jew'' derives from [[Old English language|Old English]] where the word is attested as early as 1000 in various forms, such as ''Iudeas'', ''Gyu'', ''Giu'', ''Iuu'', ''Iuw'', ''Iew''. The Old English name is derived from Old French. The modern [[French language|French]] term is "juif". Most European languages have retained the letter "d" in the word for Jew. Etymological equivalents are in use in other languages, e.g., "Jude" in [[German language|German]], "judeu" in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], "jøde" in [[Danish language|Danish]] and [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]], "judío" in [[Spanish language|Spanish]], "jood" in [[Dutch language|Dutch]], etc. In some languages, derivations of the word "Hebrew" are also in use to describe a Jew, e.g., ''Ebreo'' in [[Italian language|Italian]], ''Ebri/Ebrani'' ({{lang-fa|عبری/عبرانی}}) in [[Persian language|Persian]] and ''Еврей, Yevrey'' in [[Russian language|Russian]].{{cite book|last=Falk|first=Avner|authorlink=Avner Falk|title=A Psychoanalytic History of the Jews|year=1996|publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson University Press|location=Madison, N.J.|isbn=0-8386-3660-8|page=131 }} (See [[Jewish ethnonyms]] for a full overview.) The German word "Jude" is pronounced {{IPA-de|ˈjuːdə|}}, the corresponding [[adjective]] "jüdisch" {{IPA-de|ˈjyːdɪʃ|}} (Jewish), and is cognate with the Yiddish word for "Jew", "Yid".{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary |title=Yiddish|edition=11th|year=2004|publisher=Merriam-Webster|location=Springfield, Massachusetts|isbn=0-87779-809-5|page=1453|ref=harv }} == Modern use == {{further|Who is a Jew?}} [[File:YehudObverse.jpg|thumb|left|150 px|Obverse of a Jewish silver [[Yehud coinage|Yehud]] coin from the Persian era, with falcon or eagle and Aramaic inscription '''"יהד"''' ''"Yehud"'' ([[Judea|Judaea]])]] In [[modern English]], the term "Israelite" was used to refer to contemporary Jews as well as to Jews of antiquity until the mid-20th-century. Since the foundation of the [[State of Israel]], it has become less common to use "Israelite" of Jews in general. Instead, citizens of the state of Israel, whether Jewish or not, are called "Israeli", while "Jew" is used as an ethno-religious designation. === Antisemitism === The word ''Jew'' has been used often enough in a disparaging manner by [[Antisemitism|antisemites]] that in the late 19th and early 20th centuries it was frequently avoided altogether, and the term ''Hebrew'' was substituted instead (e.g. [[Young Men's Hebrew Association]]). Even today some people are wary of its use, and prefer to use "Jewish". Indeed, when used as an adjective (e.g. "Jew lawyer") or verb (e.g. "to jew someone"),{{cite journal | title = Notes | journal = The Nation | volume = 14 | issue = 348 | page = 137 | publisher = E. L. Godkin & Co. | location = New York | date = February 29, 1872 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jQgDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA137&dq=%22to+jew%22 | issn = 0027-8378 | accessdate = December 7, 2009}} the term ''Jew'' is purely pejorative. According to ''[[The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]]'', Fourth Edition (2000):
It is widely recognized that the attributive use of the noun ''Jew'', in phrases such as ''Jew lawyer'' or ''Jew ethics'', is both [[Vulgarism|vulgar]] and highly offensive. In such contexts ''Jewish'' is the only acceptable possibility. Some people, however, have become so wary of this construction that they have extended the stigma to any use of ''Jew'' as a noun, a practice that carries risks of its own. In a sentence such as ''There are now several Jews on the council'', which is unobjectionable, the substitution of a circumlocution like ''Jewish people'' or ''[[Person of Jewish ethnicity|persons of Jewish background]]'' may in itself cause offense for seeming to imply that Jew has a negative connotation when used as a noun.{{cite web|url=http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/Jew |title=Jew |publisher=[[The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]] |accessdate=2012-04-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805210424/http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/jew |archivedate=2011-08-05 |df= }}
In much the same manner, the [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]] term for ''Jew'' ({{lang|yi|איד}},{{lang|yi|ייִד}}) ''[[Yid]]'', (singular), {{lang|yi|ייִדן}} ''Yidn'' (plural)) — originally a benign term — was once used as an [[ethnic slur]], but now is often used by Jews in praise, to describe an upstanding religiously observant Jew (e.g., "He's such a ''Yid'', giving up his time like that") or to distinguish upstanding religiously observant Jews from non-observant, with the implication that the latter would be better people if they were stricter in their observance (e.g., "''Yidn'' wouldn't do such a thing").{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} == See also == * [[Jewish ethnonym]] in various languages * ''[[Ioudaioi]],'' Greek == References == {{Reflist}} {{Jews and Judaism}} [[Category:Jews| ]] [[Category:Etymologies|Jew]] [[Category:Ethnonyms|Jew]] [[Category:Definitions]] [[Category:English words]] [[Category:Ethnic and religious slurs]] [[he:יהודים#אטימולוגיה]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox artifact |name = Kankali Tila tablet of Sodasa |image = Kankali Tila plate of Sodasa.jpg |image_caption = The [[Kankali Tila]] tablet of Sodasa, with an inscription mentioning the year 42 of the reign of [[Northern Satraps]] ruler [[Sodasa]].<ref name="Smith">The Jain stûpa and other antiquities of Mathurâ by Smith, Vincent Arthur [https://archive.org/details/cu31924012251140 Plate XIV]</ref> |material = Red sandstone |size = |writing = |created = |period = 1st century CE |place = [[Kankali Tila]], [[Mathura]], [[India]]. |discovered_coords =27°36′00″N 77°39′00″E |location = [[State Museum Lucknow]] | map = {{Location map | India | width = 300px | float = center | border = | caption = | alt = | relief = yes | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label = [[Kankali Tila]], [[Mathura]], (Discovery) | label_size = | position = | background = | mark = | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = 27.5 | lon_deg = 77.65 }} |id = |registration = }}
[[File:Mathura archaeological sites.jpg|thumb|300px|The tablet was found in [[Kankali Tila]], right outside [[Mathura]].]] The '''Kankali Tila tablet of Sodasa''', also called the '''Iryavati stone tablet''',<ref name="SP">Cultural Contours of India: Dr. Satya Prakash Felicitation Volume, Vijai Shankar Śrivastava - 1981, p.98</ref> or '''Amohini ayagapata''',<ref>Orientalia Rheno-traiectina by Hendrik Willem Obbink, Brill Archive [https://books.google.com/books?id=0t8UAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA65 p.65]</ref> is a large stone slab discovered in [[Kankali Tila|Kankali]] (area of [[Mathura]]) which mentions the rule of the [[Northern Satraps]] ruler [[Sodasa]] in Mathura.<ref name="Smith"/> The tablet in the [[State Museum Lucknow]] (room J.1).<ref name="SP"/>
==Description== This votive tablet, which is essentially an [[ayagapata]], though not so called, represents a royal lady attended by three women and a child. The attendant women, in accordance with the ancient Indian fashion, are naked to the waist. One holds an umbrella over her mistress, whom another fans. The third holds a wreath ready for presentation. The execution is bold, and quite artistic.<ref name="Smith"/>
==Inscription== The tablet bears a three line epigraph mentioning that in the year 42 of "Lord Mahaksatrapa Sodasa," a monument for worship was set up by a certain Amohini.<ref name="Smith"/> The text is as follows :
{{quote| L1. Nama arahato Vardhamanasa 2. Sv[a]misa mahakshatrapasa Sodasasa savatsare XL(?)II hemantamase II divase IX Haritiputrasa Palasa bhayaye samasavikaye 3. Kochhiye Amohiniye saha putrehi Palaghoshena Pothaghoshena Dhanaghoshena Ayavati pratihapita praya[bha] 4. Aryavati arahatapujaye.
"Adoration to the [[Arhat]] [[Vardhamana]]! In the year 42 of the Lord, the [[Mahakshatrapa]] [[Sodasa]], in the second month of winter, on the 9th day, an Ayavati (Aryavati) was set up by Amohini (Amohint), the Kochhi (Kautsi), a female lay-disciple of the ascetics (and) wife of Pala, son of a Hariti (Hariti or Hariti mother), together with her sons Palaghosha, Pothaghosha and Dhanaghosha .... the Aryavati (is) for the worship of the Arhat." |Inscription of the Kankali Tila tablet of Sodasa (Translation by Buhler)<ref name="Smith"/> }}
==Question of the date== The inscription shows that the tablet was presented to the Jain shrine by a lady named Amohini in the year 42 or 72, in the reign of the Great Satrap Sodasa. The first numerals for the date may be read as 40, or possibly 70 (according to Buhler), so that the regnal date could be either 42 or 72 (with 72 being favoured by most).<ref name="Smith"/>
According to Smith, the initial year of the era used by the great Satrap Sodasa is not known, but the inscription may be considered as dating a few years earlier than the Christian era or the 1st century.<ref name="Smith"/> According to others, it is not known if the date 42/72 is a regnal year of Sodasa, or an era founded by his father or another ruler.<ref>From Persepolis to the Punjab, Elizabeth Errington, Vesta Sarkhosh Curtis - 2007</ref>
According to some authors, the regnal date for Sodasa was 80 CE, so that the tablet would have been dedicated in 152 CE (50+72).<ref>Chhotelal Jain's Jaina Bibliography - Volume 1 - Chhotelal Jain, Satya Ranjan Banerjee - 1982, Page 809</ref> A recent date for Sodasa's reign was given as 15 CE, meaning that the regnal date of the inscription would start from the [[Vikrama era]] started by [[Indo-Scythian]] king [[Azes I]] ([[Bikrami calendar]] (starting in 57 BCE)+72=15 CE).<ref>Image Problems: The Origin and Development of the Buddha's Image in Early South Asia Robert Daniel DeCaroli, University of Washington Press, 2015 [https://books.google.com/books?id=K8MECgAAQBAJ&pg=PA205 p.205]</ref><ref name="Maitra"/> This would put the long reign of his father [[Rajuvula]] in the last quarter of the 1st century BCE, which is probable.<ref name="Maitra">Indian Studies, Volume 7, Ramakrishna Maitra, 1966 p.67</ref>
Another inscription of the Satrap Sodasa was found by [[Alexander Cunningham]] in the Jail mound at Mathura. His coins also are found in the neighborhood.<ref name="Smith"/>

{{redirect|Shinshoku|the [[L'Arc-en-Ciel]] song|Shinshoku (Lose Control)}} [[File:Kannushi and miko at the Meiji Shrine, Tokyo.jpg|thumb|180px|left|A ''kannushi'' wearing a ''[[jōe]]'' accompanied by a ''[[miko]]'']] [[File:Shinto_priest_in_full_dress,kannushi,katori-jingu-shrine,katori-city,japan.JPG|thumb|180px|right|A ''kannushi'' in full dress, [[Katori Shrine]]]] [[File:Kannushi Kamakura.jpg|thumb|180px|right|A ''kannushi'' wearing a garment called ''kariginu'' and a hat called ebōshi]]
A {{nihongo3|"god master"|神主|'''kannushi'''|originally pronounced ''kamunushi''}}, also called {{nihongo|'''shinshoku'''|神職|extra=meaning ''god's employee''}}, is the person responsible for the maintenance of a {{nihongo|[[Shinto]] [[shinto shrine|shrine]]|神社|''jinja''}} as well as for leading worship of a given ''[[kami]]''.<ref name="IK">* ''Kannushi'' (in Japanese), Iwanami {{nihongo|[[Kōjien]]|広辞苑}} Japanese dictionary, 6th Edition (2008), DVD version</ref> The characters for ''kannushi'' are sometimes also read '''''jinshu''''' with the same meaning.
Originally the ''kannushi'' were intermediaries between ''kami'' and could transmit their will to common humans.<ref name="eos"/> A ''kannushi'' was a man capable of miracles or a holy man who, because of his practice of [[Harae|purificatory rites]], was able to work as a medium for a [[kami]]. Later the term evolved to being synonymous with ''shinshoku'', that is, a man who works at a shrine and holds religious ceremonies there.<ref name="IK"/><ref name="ya"> {{cite web |last = Moriyasu |first = Jin |title = Kannushi |language = Japanese |work = Nihon Hyakka Zensho |publisher = Shogakukan |url = http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E7%A5%9E%E4%B8%BB/ |accessdate = 2009-10-16 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6AfIob8e3?url=http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E7%A5%9E%E4%B8%BB/ |archivedate = 2012-09-14 |df =}}</ref>
In ancient times, because of the overlap of political and religious power within a clan, it was the head of the clan who led the clansmen during religious functions, or else it could be another official.<ref name="ya"/> Later, the role evolved into a separate and more specialized form. The term appears in both the ''[[Kojiki]]'' (680 AD) and ''[[Nihon Shoki]]'' (720 AD).<ref name="ya"/> In them respectively, Empress Jungū and Emperor Suijin become ''kannushi''.<ref name="eos"> {{cite web | title= Kannushi | last= Nishimuta | first= Takao | date= 2007-03-28 | work= Encyclopedia of Shinto | publisher= Kokugakuin | url= http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1285 | accessdate= 2009-10-16}}</ref>
Within the same shrine, for example at [[Ise Jingū]] or [[Ōmiwa Shrine]], there can be different types of ''kannushi'' at the same time called for example {{nihongo|''Ō-kannushi''|大神主}}, {{nihongo|''Sō-kannushi''|総神主}}, or {{nihongo|''Gon-kannushi''|権神主}}.<ref name="eos"/><ref name="ya"/>
''Kannushi'' can marry and their children usually inherit their position.<ref name="nishi"> {{cite book | last= Nishimura | first= Hajime | title= A Comparative History of Ideas | publisher= Motilal Banarsidass | year= 1998 | isbn= 978-81-208-1004-4}}</ref> Although this hereditary status is no longer legally granted, it continues in practice.<ref name="EB"> {{cite web| title= Shinshoku | publisher= Encyclopædia Britannica Online | url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/540847/shinshoku | accessdate= 2009-10-16}} </ref>
The clothes they wear, for example the ''[[jōe]]'', the ''ebōshi'' and the ''kariginu'' (see photos), do not have any special religious significance, but are simply official garments used in the past by the Imperial court.<ref name="nishi"/> This detail reveals the close connection between ''kami'' worship and the figure of the Emperor.<ref name="nishi"/> Other implements used by ''kannushi'' include a baton called ''[[Shaku (Japanese ritual baton)|shaku]]'' and a wand decorated with white paper streamers (''[[shide (Shinto)|shide]]'') called ''[[ōnusa]]''. ''Kannushi'' are assisted in their religious or clerical work by women called ''[[miko]]''.
To become a ''kannushi'', a novice must study at a university approved by the {{Nihongo|[[Association of Shinto Shrines]]|神社本庁|Jinja Honchō}}, typically [[Tokyo]]'s [[Kokugakuin University]] or [[Ise, Mie|Ise]]'s [[Kogakkan University]], or pass an exam that will certify his qualification.<ref name="EB"/> [[Women in Japan|Women]] can also become ''kannushi'' and widows can succeed their husbands in their job.<ref name="EB"/>

{{infobox ethnic group| |group= Kansara |image= |poptime = |popplace = [[India]] |langs =[[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]] |rels= [[Hinduism]] |related= [[Twashta Kasar|Tambat]] and [[Panchal]] }}
The '''Kansara''' or '''[[Thathera|Kasera]]''' are a [[Hindu]] [[caste]] found throughout India. They are mostly found in Gujarat and Maharashtra. Also found in Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, UP and Bihar. They traditionally made utensils and bells.
==Etymology== The '''Kansara''' or '''Kasera''' derived their name from ''kan̩su'' ({{lang-gu|કાંસુ}}, {{IPA-gu|kaɳsũ|IPA}}), [[bell metal]].<ref name="guj">{{cite book|title=Gujarat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4Cy_-FXW9BQC&pg=PA599|year=2003|publisher=Popular Prakashan|isbn=978-81-7991-104-4|pages=599–600}}</ref>
==History== Their mythical history associates them with [[Parshurama]] (sixth [[avatar]] of [[Vishnu]]) who exterminated the [[Kshatriya]]s. It is said that the Kansaras were Kshatriyas who hid their identity by selling utensils to save their lives. Later, selling utensils became their caste occupation. This story is told in the ''[[Kalika Purana]]'', named after their deity [[Kali]].<ref name="guj"/>
==Caste groups== The Kansara belongs to [[Gujarat]], India. Their associated groups live in Maharashtra such as Tambat.<ref name="Bhanu2004">{{cite book |author=B. V. Bhanu |title=People of India: Maharashtra |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BsBEgVa804IC&pg=PA929 |year=2004 |publisher=Popular Prakashan |isbn=978-81-7991-101-3 |pages=929–930}}</ref>
The Kansara are divided into Gujarati Kansara, Maru Kansara, Sorathia Kansara, and Jamnagari Kansara,Surti Kansara, based on their native place. The Gujarati Kansara live in [[Wadhwan]], [[Surendranagar]], [[Rajkot]], [[Bhavnagar]], and [[Dhrangdhra]]. They speak the [[Kathiawar]] dialect of Gujarati. They traditionally wear [[kanthi mala]].<ref name="guj"/>
In other states there is no concentration of the people in any particular region and can be found in almost all the places.
People living in Gujarat and Maharashtra are vegetarian.<ref name="guj"/><ref name="Bhanu2004"/> People living in other places have mixed eating habits.

{{Expert-subject|date=July 2011}} {{redirect|Mekhala|Buddhist ''mahasiddha''|Mekhala and Kanakhala}} [[File:Mekkala and Ramasura.png|thumb|300px|Illustrated of Mekhala and Ramasura, from a [[samut khoi]] of Thai poetry in the second half of the 19th century. now collection in [[Bavarian State Library]], [[Germany]].]] '''Manimekhala''' ({{lang-km|មណីមេខលា}}, ''Moni Mekhala''; {{lang-th|มณีเมขลา}}, ''Mani Mekkhala'') is a goddess in the Hindu-buddhist mythology. She is regarded as a guardian of the seas; namely the [[Indian Ocean]] and the [[South China Sea]] as part of the mythology of [[Indochina]]. She was placed by Catummaharajika to protect virtuous beings from shipwreck.<ref>G.P. Malalasekera. Dictionary of Pali Proper Names: Pali-English. Asian Educational Services, 2003</ref> She appears in several Buddhist stories including the Mahajanaka-[[Jataka]] in which she rescues Prince Mahajanaka from a shipwreck.<ref name="Monius">Anne Elizabeth Monius. Imagining a place for Buddhism: literary culture and religious community in Tamil-speaking South India. Oxford University Press US, 2001, pages 111-112</ref>
==Etymology== In [[Pali]], ''{{lang|pi|maņīmekhalā}}'' refers to a girdle or belt of jewels. In Indochina, she is sometimes referred to simply as Mekhala; ''Neang Mekhala'' ({{lang-km|នាងមេខលា}}) in Cambodia and ''Mekkhala'' ({{lang-th|เมขลา}}) in Thailand. Her name was contributed by Thailand for tropical cyclone names occurring as '[[Tropical Storm Mekkhala (disambiguation)|Tropical Storm Mekkhala]]' in 2002 and 2008.
==In Mainland Southeast Asia== Manimekhala is seen in [[wat]] paintings across [[Mainland Southeast Asia]] depicting scenes from Mahajanaka.<ref name="Monius" /> In Thailand and Cambodia, she is considered a goddess of lightning and the seas. In the classical dance traditions of Thailand and Cambodia, sacred dramatic dances depict the goddess Manimekhala, Ramasura ([[Parashurama]]), and [[Arjuna]]; according to legend, the phenomena of [[thunder]] and [[lightning]] is produced in the clash of Manimekhala's crystal ball and Parashurama's axe. In Cambodia, these dance dramas are used in propitiation ceremonies called ''buong suong tevoda'' and were performed to invoke the rains to fall.<ref>Cravath, Paul. Asian Theatre Journal, Vol. 3, No. 2 (Autumn, 1986), pp. 179-203 (The Ritual Origins of the Classical Dance Drama of Cambodia) University of Hawai'i Press</ref>
==In Sri Lanka== In Sri Lanka, she is considered to be the sea goddess. In the [[Tamil language|Tamil]] epic poem, the [[Manimekalai]], she puts the eponymous herioine to sleep and takes her to the island Maṇipallavam ([[Nainatheevu]]). In the mythic cycle of the god Devol, when the latter approaches Sri Lanka and his ship founders, it is Manimekhalai, on the instructions of the god [[Śakra (Buddhism)|Śakra]], who conjures up a stone boat to save him.

page.title: Marriage in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

revision.comment: /* Interracial marriage */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: native Americans → Native Americans (2)
revision.text:
In [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]], '''marriage''' between a man and a woman is considered to be "ordained of God".<ref name= "Family Proclamation" >{{citation |author= [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]] and [[Quorum of the Twelve Apostles (LDS Church)|Council of the Twelve Apostles]] |date= September 23, 1995 |contribution= The Family: A Proclamation to the World |url= http://www.lds.org/topics/family-proclamation |title= Gospel Topics |publisher= LDS Church |accessdate= 2013-12-11 }}. See also: "[[The Family: A Proclamation to the World]]".</ref> Marriage is thought to consist of a [[covenant (Latter Day Saints)|covenant]] between the man, the woman, and God. The church teaches that in addition to civil marriage, which ends at death, a man and woman can undergo a [[celestial marriage]] in a [[temple (LDS Church)|temple]] performed by [[priesthood (LDS Church)|priesthood]] authority, whereby the marriage and parent–child relationships resulting from the marriage will last forever in the [[afterlife]].<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.lds.org/topics/temples |contribution= Temples |title= Gospel Topics |publisher= LDS Church }}</ref>
From 1852 until 1890, the LDS Church openly authorized [[plural marriage|polygamous marriages]] between one man and multiple wives, though polygamous families continued cohabitating into the 1940s and 1950s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Embry|first1=Jessie L.|title=The History of Polygamy|url=https://heritage.utah.gov/history/uhg-history-polygamy-2|website=heritage.utah.gov|publisher=Utah State Historical Society|year=1994|quote=Those involved in plural marriages after 1904 were excommunicated; and those married between 1890 and 1904 were not to have church callings where other members would have to sustain them. Although the Mormon church officially prohibited new plural marriages after 1904, many plural husbands and wives continued to cohabit until their deaths in the 1940s and 1950s.}}</ref><ref>Leaders of the church secretly practiced and taught plural marriage from about 1831 to 1852.</ref> Today, the church is opposed to such marriages and excommunicates members who participate in them or publicly teach that they are sanctioned by God. The LDS Church also opposes the legalization of same-sex marriage.<ref>Fred Karger, [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/29/mormon-church-gay-marriage-lobbying "The Mormon church won't drop its opposition to gay marriage"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2013-11-29.</ref>
==Teachings about marriage in general== A spouse is the only person other than the Lord that Latter-day Saints are commanded to love "with all [their] heart". A [[revelation (Latter Day Saints)|revelation]] in the [[Doctrine and Covenants]] states: "Thou shalt love thy wife with all thy heart, and shalt cleave unto her and none else."<ref name=DC42>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|42|22}}</ref> Church leaders have taught that this commandment applies equally to wives loving their husbands.<ref>[[Spencer W. Kimball]], [http://www.lds.org/liahona/1978/06/oneness-in-marriage "Oneness in Marriage"], ''[[Tambuli]]'', June 1978.</ref><ref>[[Marlin K. Jensen]], [http://www.lds.org/ensign/1994/10/a-union-of-love-and-understanding "A Union of Love and Understanding"], ''[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]]'' October 1994.</ref>
The LDS Church also teaches that marriage is a partnership of equals, and that partners should be thoughtful, respectful, and loyal to one another.<ref name = website>{{citation |url= http://www.lds.org/topics/marriage |contribution= Marriage |title= Gospel Topics |publisher= LDS Church |quote= Marriage is a partnership of equals, with neither person exercising dominion over the other, but with each encouraging, comforting, and helping the other .... it needs and deserves time over less-important commitments. Couples can strengthen their marriage as they take time to talk together and to listen to one another, to be thoughtful and respectful, and to express tender feelings and affection often... Marriage partners must be loyal to one another and faithful in their marriage covenants in thought, word, and deed. Married couples should stay away from anything that could lead to unfaithfulness in any way. Pornography, unwholesome fantasies, and flirtations will erode character and strike at the foundation of marriage. }}</ref> The church teaches that if couples keep their lives centered on Jesus Christ, their love will grow.<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.lds.org/topics/marriage |contribution= Marriage |title= Gospel Topics |publisher= LDS Church |quote= Couples must center their lives in the gospel of Jesus Christ. As couples help one another keep the covenants they have made, attend church and the temple together, study the scriptures together, and kneel together in prayer, God will guide them. Their companionship will sweeten through the years; their love will strengthen. Their appreciation for one another will grow. }}</ref> Regarding marriage and divorce, the church instructs its leaders: "No priesthood officer is to counsel a person whom to marry. Nor should he counsel a person to divorce his or her spouse. Those decisions must originate and remain with the individual. When a marriage ends in divorce, or if a husband and wife separate, they should always receive counseling from Church leaders."<ref>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Stake Presidents and Bishops]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) § 7.2.5.</ref>
==Teachings about celestial marriage== {{main|Celestial marriage}} [[celestial marriage|Celestial (or eternal) marriage]] is an [[ordinance (Latter Day Saints)|ordinance]] performed by [[priesthood (Mormonism)|priesthood]] authority in a [[Temple (LDS Church)|temple]] of the church.<ref name = marriagegp/> A celestial marriage is thought to continue forever into the [[afterlife]] if the man and woman do not break their covenants.<ref name = marriagegp>[http://www.lds.org/manual/gospel-principles/chapter-38-eternal-marriage "Chapter 38: Eternal Marriage"], ''[[Gospel Principles]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2011).</ref> Thus, eternally married couples are often referred to as being "[[Sealing (Latter Day Saints)|sealed]]" to each other. Sealed couples who keep their covenants are also promised to have their posterity sealed to them in the afterlife.<ref name = marriagegp/>
===Celestial marriage as a requirement for exaltation=== The LDS Church teaches that a [[celestial marriage]] is required for [[exaltation (Latter Day Saints)|exaltation]].<ref name = marriagegp/> This teaching is based on Mormon [[standard works|scripture]], in which [[Joseph Smith]] taught, “In the celestial glory there are three heavens or degrees; and in order to obtain the highest, a man must enter into this order of the priesthood [meaning the new and everlasting covenant of marriage]; and if he does not, he cannot obtain it. He may enter into the other, but that is the end of his kingdom; he cannot have an increase”.<ref>{{lds|Doctrine and Covenants|dc|131|1|4}}</ref> Exaltation is also known as "eternal life" and is defined as "the kind of life God lives".<ref name = exaltationgp>[http://www.lds.org/manual/gospel-principles/chapter-47-exaltation "Chapter 47: Exaltation"], ''[[Gospel Principles]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2011).</ref> Those who are exalted will "live eternally in the presence of Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ[;] will become gods[;] will be united eternally with their righteous family members and will be able to have eternal increase [spirit children][; and] will have everything that our Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ have—all power, glory, dominion, and knowledge".<ref name = exaltationgp/> Members of the LDS Church are encouraged to prepare to be celestially married in a temple.<ref>{{Citation |last= Bushman |first= Richard L. |authorlink= Richard L. Bushman |year= 2008 |title= Mormonism: a Very Short Introduction |location= New York |publisher= [[Oxford University Press]] |isbn= 9780195310306 |oclc= 179802646 |pages= 58–59 }}</ref>
It is believed, therefore, that all humans are spirit children of "heavenly parents"<ref name= "Family Proclamation"/> who as mortals were celestially married and went on to become exalted. This married couple is known to Latter-day Saints as [[God the Father]] and [[Heavenly Mother (Mormonism)|Heavenly Mother]]. Because of the beliefs that (1) celestial marriage is required for exaltation, and (2) that Jesus is exalted, some leaders of the LDS Church have hypothesized that [[Jesus]] must have been married, possibly to [[Mary Magdalene]], [[Mary, sister of Lazarus]], and/or [[Martha]].<ref>{{Citation| last1=Hyde| first1=Orson | authorlink=Orson Hyde| contribution=The Marriage Relations| date=October 6, 1854| title=[[Journal of Discourses]]| editor1-last=Watt | editor1-first=G.D.| editor1-link=George D. Watt| volume=2| place=Liverpool| publisher=[[Franklin D. Richards (Mormon apostle)|F. D. Richards]]| pages=75–87| contribution-url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Journal_of_Discourses/Volume_2/The_Marriage_Relations}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation| last1=Hyde| first1=Orson| authorlink=Orson Hyde| contribution=Man the Head of Woman—Kingdom of God—The Seed of Christ—Polygamy—Society in Utah| year=185| title=[[Journal of Discourses]]| editor1-last=Watt | editor1-first=G.D.| editor1-link=George D. Watt| volume=4| place=Liverpool| publisher=S. W. Richards| pages=257–263| contribution-url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Journal_of_Discourses/Volume_4/Man_the_Head_of_Woman%2C_etc.}}.</ref><ref>{{citation |authorlink= Orson Pratt |first= Orson |last= Pratt |contribution= Celestial Marriage |title= [[The Seer (periodical)|The Seer]] |volume= 1 |issue= 10 |page= 159 |date=October 1853 |contribution-url= http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/NCMP1820-1846/id/18108 }}</ref><ref>[[Wilford Woodruff]], Journal Entry 1883-07-22, reporting on a sermon given by [[Joseph F. Smith]].</ref><ref>[[Joseph Fielding Smith]], [http://www.mrm.org/files/images/was-jesus-married-letter.jpg Handwritten note responding to letter from J. Ricks Smith], 1963.</ref>
Because it is a requirement for exaltation, celestial marriages are performed vicariously in church temples for deceased couples who were legally married.
==Civil marriage and divorce and its relationship to celestial marriage== In some legal jurisdictions, celestial marriages can be recognized as civil marriages; in other cases, couples are civilly married outside of the temple and are later sealed in a celestial marriage.<ref>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Stake Presidents and Bishops]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) § 3.5.</ref> The church will no longer perform a celestial marriage on a couple unless they are first (or simultaneously) legally married.
A celestial marriage is not annulled by a civil divorce: a "cancellation of a sealing" may be granted, but only by the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]], the highest authority in the church. Civil divorce and marriage outside the temple carry with them a stigma in Mormon culture; the church teaches that the "gospel of Jesus Christ—including repentance, forgiveness, integrity, and love—provides the remedy for conflict in marriage.<ref>[http://www.lds.org/topics/divorce "Gospel Topics: Divorce"], lds.org.</ref>
==Polygamy== {{main|Mormonism and polygamy}} Until 1890, the LDS Church openly sanctioned [[plural marriage]], which was the practice of marrying a man celestially to multiple women. Such polygamous marriages were celestial marriages only, not legal civil marriages. Today, the church is opposed to such marriages and excommunicates members who participate in them, whether or not polygamy is legal in the jurisdiction in question. The church teaches that “the standard doctrine of the church is monogamy" and that polygamy was a temporary exception to the rule.<ref>[http://www.mormonnewsroom.org/article/polygamy-latter-day-saints-and-the-practice-of-plural-marriage "Polygamy: Latter-day Saints and the Practice of Plural Marriage"], LDS Newsroom, mormonnewsroom.org.</ref> Early church leaders taught that God the Father and Jesus Christ both practiced polygamy in defense of the practice, a belief widely accepted among Mormons by the late-1850s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Swanson|first1=Vern G.|title=Dynasty of the Holy Grail: Mormonism's Holy Bloodline|date=2013|publisher=Cedar Fort, Inc.|location=Springville, UT|isbn=9781462104048|chapter=Christ and Polygamy|page=247–259|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rss1CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT251&lpg=PT251&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false|quote=Dr. William E. Phipps noted that the belief that 'Jesus married, and married often!' was used to encourage and promote the doctrine of polygamy amongst timid Latter-Day Saints ... By the late-1850s the idea that more than one woman was married to Jesus was widely accepted among Mormon circles. ... As if the concept of Christ's polygamy was not unsettling enough, Mormonism even taught in the nineteenth century that God the Father had a plurality of wives as well.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dana|first1=Bruce E.|title=The Eternal Father and His Son|date=September 2004|page=62|publisher=Cedar Fort Inc.|isbn=1555177883|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-z8NVySmnmcC&ots=zbVT_DkTjy&pg=PA62#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=9 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Schelling Durham|first1=Michael|title=Desert Between the Mountains: Mormons, Miners, Padres, Mountain Men, and the Opening of the Great Basin, 1772-1869|date=1997|publisher=Henry Holt & Company, Inc.|location=New York City|page=182|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=df57AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA182#v=onepage&q&f=false|quote=Pratt clearly loud out arguments in favor of polygamy that the Saints would use for years to come. ... Pratt and others argued that Jesus had three wives: Mary Magdalene, and Lazarus' two sisters, Mary and Martha. Orson Hyde went a step further and preached that 'Jesus Christ was married at Cana of Galilee, that Mary, Martha, and others were his wives, and that he begat children.'}}</ref>
==Interracial marriage== {{Main article|Interracial marriage and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints}} In the past, LDS Church leaders have consistently opposed marriage between different [[ethnicity|ethnicities]] with the apostle [[Boyd K. Packer|Boyd Packer]] publicly stating in 1977 that "We've always counseled in the Church for ... our Caucasians to marry Caucasians .... The counsel has been wise."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Packer|first1=Boyd|title=Follow the Rule|url=https://speeches.byu.edu/talks/boyd-k-packer_follow-rule/|website=byu.edu|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=26 August 2017|quote=We’ve always counseled in the Church for our Mexican members to marry Mexicans, our Japanese members to marry Japanese, our Caucasians to marry Caucasians, our Polynesian members to marry Polynesians. The counsel has been wise. ... You might even say, “I can show you local Church leaders or perhaps even general leaders who have married out of their race.” I say, “Yes—exceptions.” Then I would remind you of that Relief Society woman’s near-scriptural statement, “We’d like to follow the rule first, and then we’ll take care of the exceptions.”}}</ref> Nearly every decade beginning with the church's formation until the '70s has seen some denunciation against miscegenation, with most focusing on black-white marriage. These church leaders' views stem from racist "biological and social" principles.<ref name="Neither White Nor Black" >{{cite book |editor-last= Bush |editor-first= Lester E., Jr. |editor2-last= Mauss |editor2-first= Armand L. |editor2-link= Armand L. Mauss |title= Neither White Nor Black: Mormon Scholars Confront the Race Issue in a Universal Church |publisher= [[Signature Books]] |year= 1984 |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |url= http://signaturebookslibrary.org/?p=438 |isbn= 0-941214-22-2}}</ref>{{rp|89-90}}<ref name=BushDialogue>{{cite journal |last1=Bush |first1=Lester E. |date=1973 |title= Mormonism’s Negro Doctrine: An Historical Overview|url=https://www.dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V08N01_13.pdf |journal=Dialogue |volume=8 |issue=1 |}}</ref>{{rp|42-43}} One exception was intermarriage with Native Americans, who Mormons believed to be [[Lamanites]], a race descended from ancient [[Israelites]].<ref name="Mauss 2003">{{cite book |title=All Abraham's Children: Changing Mormon Conceptions of Race and Lineage |first=Armand L. |last=Mauss |publisher=University of Illinois Press |year=2003 |isbn=0-252-02803-1}}</ref>{{rp|64}} Intermarriage with Native Americans was actually encouraged as a way to fulfill a Book of Mormon prophecy that the Lamanites would become white and delightsome.<ref>{{cite book|title=Race and the Making of the Mormon People|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hB8wDwAAQBAJ|author=Max Perry Mueller}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TgQxDwAAQBAJ|title=Doing the Works of Abraham: Mormon Polygamy—Its Origin, Practice, and Demise|authors=B. Carmon Hardy}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7xUkDQAAQBAJ|title=Sweet Freedom's Plains: African Americans on the Overland Trails, 1841–1869|author=Shirley Ann Wilson Moore}}</ref>
Church publications have also contained statements discouraging interracial marriage. In the same June 1978 issue announcing that black members were now eligible for temple rites, missionary service, and priesthood ordination, the official newspaper of the LDS Church,<ref>{{Cite journal |author=Paul T. Roberts |title=A History of the Development and Objectives of the LDS Church News Section of the Deseret News |series=[Master's Thesis] |publisher=Provo, Utah: [[Brigham Young University]], Department of Communications |date=August 1983 |page=7 |url=http://scholarsarchive.byu.edu/etd/5078/ |format=PDF |accessdate=October 29, 2014}}</ref> printed an article entitled "Interracial marriage discouraged".<ref name="Discouraged">{{cite news|title=Interracial Marriage Discouraged|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19780617&id=_RxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YIADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5866,5012493|accessdate=27 August 2017|work=Church News|agency=Deseret News|publisher=LDS Church|date=17 June 1978|quote=For a number of years, President Spencer W. Kimball has counseled young members of the Church to not cross racial lines in dating and marrying.}}</ref> The same day a church spokesman stated "interracial marriages generally have been discouraged in the past, ... that remains our position" and that "the Church does not prohibit ... interracial marriages but it does discourage them."<ref name="black and mormon">{{cite book |editor1-last= Bringhurst |editor1-first= Newell G. |editor2-last= Smith |editor2-first= Darron T. |title=Black and Mormon |year=2004 |publisher=University of Illinois Press |isbn=0252073568 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lSvRnQgJAx8C&lpg=PA7&pg=PP7#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>{{rp|5}}
In 2003 author [[Jon Krakauer|Jon Krakauer's]] stated that "official LDS policy has continued to strongly admonish white saints not to marry blacks" in his "[[Under the Banner of Heaven]]". In response the church newsroom released a statement from BYU Dean of Religious Education [[Robert L. Millet|Robert Millet]] that "There is, in fact, no mention whatsoever in [the church] [[Handbook (LDS Church)|handbook]] concerning interracial marriages. In addition, having served as a Church leader for almost 30 years, I can also certify that I have never received official verbal instructions condemning marriages between black and white members."<ref>Robert L. Millet, [http://www.mormonnewsroom.org/article/church-response-to-jon-krakauers-under-the-banner-of-heaven "Church Response to Jon Krakauer's Under the Banner of Heaven"], June 27, 2003.</ref> Though, denying any condemnation of interracial marriage, there was no comment on whether it was still discouraged, however.
The discouragement of marriage between those of different ethnicities by church leaders continued being taught to youth during Sunday meetings until 2013 when the use of the 1996 version of the church Sunday meeting manual for adolescent boys was discontinued. The manual had used a 1976 quote from past church president [[Spencer W. Kimball|Spencer Kimball]] that said, "We recommend that people marry those who are of the same racial background generally".<ref name="Black Saints">{{cite book|last1=Embry|first1=Jessie L.|title=Black Saints in a White Church|date=1994|publisher=Signature Books|isbn=1-56085-044-2|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/social-acceptance/|accessdate=26 August 2017}}</ref>{{rp|169}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Lesson 31: Choosing an Eternal Companion |url=//www.lds.org/manual/aaronic-priesthood-manual-3/lesson-31-choosing-an-eternal-companion |work=Aaronic Priesthood Manual 3 |publisher=LDS Church |year=1995 |pages=127–29}}</ref> The quote is still in use, however, in the 2003 institute Eternal Marriage Student Manual.<ref>{{cite book|title=Eternal Marriage Student Manual|url=https://www.lds.org/manual/eternal-marriage-student-manual/marriage-for-eternity?lang=eng|quote=We recommend that people marry those who are of the same racial background generally, and of somewhat the same economic and social and educational background (some of those are not an absolute necessity, but preferred), and above all, the same religious background, without question|year=2003}}</ref>
==Marriage statistics for Latter-day Saints==
In 2008 the [[American Religious Identification Survey]] reported: "Mormons have the highest proportions of currently married adults, and lowest divorce rates reflecting the emphasis on family values in this tradition .... Commitment to 'traditional or normative family values' is measured by creating a combined index of the proportions divorced and cohabiting, whereby those traditions that score lowest are the most familial. The tradition with the lowest percentages on this index are Mormons (11%)".<ref>{{citation |url= http://commons.trincoll.edu/aris/files/2011/08/ARIS_Report_2008.pdf |page= 13 |title= American Religious Identification Survey 2008: Summary Report |date=March 2009 |first= Barry A. |last= Kosmin |first2= Ariela |last2= Keysar |publisher= [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College (Hartford, Connecticut)]] }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} '''Maate Mahadevi''' B.Sc., M.A. (born 13 March 1946) is a scholar, mystic, and writer, and the first female ''Jagadguru'', or spiritual head of a South Indian [[Lingayat]] community.<ref>{{cite book |author=Werner, Karel |title=The Yogi and the mystic: studies in Indian and comparative mysticism |publisher=Curzon |location=Surrey |year=1989 |pages= |isbn=0-7007-0272-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p7J-Gy7PSSEC&q=Mate+Mahadevi#v=snippet&q=Mate%20Mahadevi&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=July–December 2009|title=The Contemporary Hindu Women of India: An Overview|journal=South Asian Studies: A Research Journal of South Asian Studies|volume=24|issue=2|pages=242–249|url=http://pu.edu.pk/csas/journal/PDF/5-Dr.%20Tahira.pdf|author=Tahira Basharat}}</ref>
Following initiation in 1965 by Lingananda Swami, Maate Mahadevi began writing ''[[vachanas]]'', a form of didactic poetry. In 1966 she received her [[Jangama]] initiation as an [[ascetic]] in the Lingayat order of wandering mendicants. In 1970 she was installed as a ''jagadguru'' in the Lingayat community, the first time a woman had been placed in that position. She holds the 12th century woman poet [[Akka Mahadevi]], who also wrote ''vachanas'', as her role model.<ref name="Sharma">{{cite book |author=Sharma, Arvind| author2=Young, Katherine K. |title=Feminism and World Religions |publisher=SUNY Press |location=New York |year=1999 |pages=45–46 |isbn=0-7914-4024-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fkay_WoTdHcC}}</ref><ref>[http://www.lingayathism.net/html/modules/cjaycontent/index.php?id=83 Lingayathism website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809153539/http://www.lingayathism.net/html/modules/cjaycontent/index.php?id=83 |date=2010-08-09 }}</ref>
By 1983 she had published twenty books and started an educational and religious institution called Jaganmata Akka Mahadevi Ashrama in [[Dharwad]], [[Karnataka]], whose focus is education and spiritual upliftment of girls and women. Among her many books is ''Basava Tatva Darshana'', on the life and teachings of [[Basava]], a 12th-century social reformer and philosopher who fought against the caste system.<ref name="Sharma" />

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Nicolae Dumitru (N. D.) Cocea | image = Cocea 1930s.JPG | caption = Late 1930s photograph of Cocea | pseudonym = Nely | birth_date = {{Birth date|1880|11|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Bârlad]], [[Romania]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1949|2|1|1880|11|29|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Sighișoara]] | occupation = journalist, critic, novelist, politician, activist, lawyer | nationality = Romanian | period = ca. 1898-1949 | genre = [[satire]], [[parody]], [[essay]], [[prose poetry]], [[erotic literature]], [[political novel]], [[travel writing]] | movement = [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]], [[Literary naturalism|Naturalism]], [[Modernist literature|Modernism]] | website = }} '''N. D. Cocea''' (common rendition of '''Nicolae Dumitru Cocea''', {{IPA-ro|nikoˈla.e duˈmitru ˈkot͡ʃe̯a}}, also known as '''Niculae''', '''Niculici''' or '''Nicu Cocea'''; November 29, 1880 – February 1, 1949) was a Romanian journalist, novelist, critic and [[left-wing]] political activist, known as a major but controversial figure in the field of political [[satire]]. The founder of many newspapers and magazines, including ''[[Viața Socială]]'', ''[[Rampa (Romanian magazine)|Rampa]]'', ''[[Facla]]'' and ''[[Chemarea]]'', collaborating with writer friends such as [[Tudor Arghezi]], [[Gala Galaction]] and [[Ion Vinea]], he fostered and directed the development of early [[modernist literature]] in Romania. Cocea later made his name as a [[Republicanism|republican]] and [[Anticlericalism|anticlerical]] agitator, was arrested as an instigator during the [[1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt|1907 peasant revolt]], and played a leading role in regrouping the scattered [[Socialism|socialist]] clubs. His allegiances however switched between parties: during [[World War I]], he supported the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]] and, as a personal witness of the [[October Revolution]], the government of [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]], before returning home as a [[Communism|communist]].
During the [[interwar period]], Cocea was elected to [[Parliament of Romania|Romanian Parliament]] as an independent socialist, campaigned for the outlawed [[Romanian Communist Party]], and found his press banned by the authorities on several occasions. In 1923, he was found guilty of ''[[lèse majesté]]''. Cocea, although kept under constant surveillance, was rumored to have been an opportunistic double dealer, and his personal life was a matter of public scandal. His novels, the vast majority of which are samples of [[erotic literature]], fueled innuendo about his sexual exploits, which also resulted in his sentencing for [[statutory rape]]. After [[World War II]], Cocea was again close to the Communist Party and, from 1948, rose to prominence as an official writer for the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]].
For a while the son-in-law of journalist [[Constantin Mille]], N. D. Cocea was from a theatrical family: his daughters [[Dina Cocea|Dina]] and [[Tantzi Cocea|Tantzi]], like his sister [[Alice Cocéa|Alice]] before them, were acclaimed actresses. Another daughter, [[Ioana-Maria Cocea]], is a noted sculptor.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Born in [[Bârlad]], Cocea claimed lineage from the lesser [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar]] aristocracy of [[Moldavia]].<ref>Călinescu, p.919; Camboulives, p.183</ref><ref name="msraristocratia">Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, "Despre aristocrația românească în timpul regimului comunist", in [[Lucian Boia]] (ed.), ''Miturile comunismului românesc'', [[Editura Nemira]], Bucharest, 1998, p.352. {{ISBN|973-569-209-0}}</ref><ref name="stamoral1">[[Stelian Tănase]], [http://www.sferapoliticii.ro/sfera/136/art11-arhiva.html "N.D. Cocea, un boier amoral/N.D. Cocea, an Immoral Boyar" (I)], in ''[[Sfera Politicii]]'', Nr. 136</ref> His father, Dumitru Cocea, was a [[Romanian Land Forces]] officer, who would reach the rank of General.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="mdsalice">{{ro icon}} [[Mihai Dim. Sturdza]], [http://www.revista22.ro/alice-cocea-9653.html "Alice Cocea"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 1087, January 2011</ref><ref name="ssscandaluri">{{ro icon}} Simina Stan, [http://www.jurnalul.ro/special/special/scandalurile-familiei-cocea-567192.html "Scandalurile familiei Cocea"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', February 5, 2011</ref><ref>Călinescu, p.919; Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.18</ref> The Coceas descended from an 18th-century [[Albanians of Romania|Albanian Moldavian]] ''[[Serdar (Ottoman rank)|Serdar]]'' Gheorghe Cocea,<ref name="gc919">Călinescu, p.919</ref> but claimed lineage from a 16th-century soldier in the armies of [[Michael the Brave]].<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> Nicolae's mother, Cleopatra, was a published author and a journalist.<ref name="stamoral1"/> She hailed from a family of [[yeomen]] (''răzeși'')<ref name="gc919"/> or landowners, and her artistic education helped shape his cultural tastes from early childhood.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.18</ref> Although he made his name as a writer and journalist, his most ardent wish was to become an actor.<ref name="ssscandaluri"/>
Nicolae attended primary school in his native town, and had a hectic adolescence, determined by his father's successive postings.<ref name="gc919"/> He is known to have first been enlisted at the National High School of [[Iași]].<ref name="cp-c220">Popescu-Cadem, p.220</ref> During the late 1890s, young Cocea was in [[Bucharest]], attending the [[Saint Sava National College]], becoming close friends with two other students and future writers: one was Galaction, the other was [[Vasile Demetrius]]. Another Saint Sava student, [[Ion G. Duca]] (the [[Prime Minister of Romania]] in 1933), was occasionally present among them, but political differences drew them apart with time.<ref name="zogalaction">{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/ediia_galaction "Ediția Galaction"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 47/2001</ref> Despite oral tradition, Arghezi, who joined the Cocea group around the same time, may not have been a Saint Sava student at all: according to literary historian C. Popescu-Cadem, there is no record of him ever attending that institution.<ref>Popescu-Cadem, p.219-222</ref> Cocea's own education was vague. He flunked out after the 3rd and 7th grades, was transferred to [[Ploiești]], then returned to Saint Sava only to pass reexamination.<ref name="cp-c220"/>
Cocea and his Saint Sava friends were already leftists who attended the public lectures of senior [[Socialism|socialist]] leader [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]].<ref name="tv280">Vianu, p.280</ref> According to literary historian [[Tudor Vianu]], the four youths, including the "restless, daring and ingenious" Cocea, were mounting an independent protest against "[[bourgeois]]" values.<ref>Vianu, p.279-280</ref> They literary taste favored [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]], [[Parnassianism]] and [[literary naturalism]], which they saw as modern shields against traditionalist culture.<ref name="tv280"/> Inspired by the works of [[Charles Baudelaire]],<ref>Vianu, p.280-281; Pastia, p.290</ref> they soon joined efforts with the [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Romanian Symbolist movement]]. All members of the group visited with the Symbolist doyen [[Alexandru Macedonski]],<ref name="tv280"/> although Cocea the writer was first discovered by Symbolist academic [[Ovid Densusianu]] and his ''[[Vieața Nouă]]'' review.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.194</ref>
As his personal note, Cocea rebelled against paternal and institutional authority. Under the pen name ''Nely'', he published the defiantly erotic novel ''Poet-Poetă'' (1898, with a preface by Galaction), that resulted in his near-definitive expulsion from public high school.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.18. See also Călinescu, p.919, 1026</ref> Around the same time, Galaction married Cocea's cousin Zoe Marcou, a laicized [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]] nun; she would inspire him to become an Orthodox priest.<ref name="zogalaction"/>
Around 1900, Cocea, who had already graduated in Romanian Law,<ref name="stamoral2">{{ro icon}} [[Stelian Tănase]], [http://www.sferapoliticii.ro/sfera/137/art11-arhiva.html "N.D. Cocea, un boier amoral" (II)], in ''[[Sfera Politicii]]'', Nr. 137</ref> was in France, undergoing specialization at the [[University of Paris]]. At this stage in life, he was probably acquainted with the French roots of Romanian [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|radical liberalism]], which infused his left-wing outlook.<ref>Camboulives, p.183; Mitchievici, p.127. See also Călinescu, p.919</ref> A sympathizer of the [[Dreyfus affair|Dreyfusards]], he was also becoming interested in the various projects to transform the [[Kingdom of Romania]] into a republic,<ref name="bc184">Camboulives, p.184</ref> in marked contrast to his father's ardent [[monarchism]].<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> He witnessed first-hand the progress of [[trade union]]ism in France, and had personal interviews with writer [[Anatole France]] and sculptor [[Auguste Rodin]].<ref name="pc29">Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.29</ref> The family's French connections were preserved by the writer's siblings. Cocea's sister [[Alice Cocéa|Alice]], the future comedian, was born in [[Sinaia]], where Dumitru Cocea was stationed in 1899, and also settled in France at a later date.<ref name="mdsalice"/> She was joined there by Cocea's younger sister, Florica.<ref name="mdsalice"/>
Upon his return to Romania, Cocea was for a while employed as [[justice of the peace]],<ref>Camboulives, p.183-184</ref> but was later virtually inactive as a lawyer.<ref name="stamoral2"/> Instead, he began frequenting the Romanian socialist milieu. He was at the time married to Florica Mille, daughter of [[Constantin Mille]]. Her father was founder of ''[[Adevărul]]'' daily and co-founder of the [[Romanian Social-Democratic Workers' Party|Social-Democratic Workers' Party]] (PSDMR). This was another break with the Cocea family tradition: allegedly, General Dumitru Cocea had once ordered his troops to devastate the ''Adevărul'' offices.<ref>Petrescu, p.109</ref>
Florica was born from Mille's first marriage, which ended in divorce, and had a sister, Margareta, married into the Messerschmitt family of German industrialists.<ref>Călinescu, p.549, 919</ref> Through Mille, Cocea became related to another Moldavian boyar family, the Tăutus.<ref name="msraristocratia"/> Cocea's marriage, which resulted in the 1912 birth of [[Dina Cocea]], was troubled and ended in divorce.<ref name="ssscandaluri"/>
===Socialist clubs and 1907 revolt=== Like some of the veteran socialists ([[Garabet Ibrăileanu]], [[Henric Sanielevici]], the ''[[România Muncitoare]]'' group), the young journalist made repeated attempts to revive and reunite the socialist clubs, left in disarray by the 1899 dissolution of the PSDMR.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.29, 133-134, 140. See also Cioroianu, p.135</ref> Cocea, with Arghezi, Demetrius and Galaction, stood out for marrying this political ideal with the artistic credo of Symbolism. This unusual vision was preserved in the magazine the three published together during 1904, ''Linia Dreaptă'' ("The Straight Line").<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.29. See also Călinescu, p.678, 682, 808; Vianu, p.478</ref> In 1905, Arghezi left for Switzerland and entrusted Cocea with his collection of rare books. Cocea is said to have lost it, an event which marked the first of several disagreements between them.<ref>Anghel, p.45</ref>
With the [[1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt|March 1907 peasant uprising]], N. D. Cocea's profile in political journalism was boosted. He is the probable source of a much circulated canard, taken up by ''Adevărul'', according to which Romanian authorities had killed 11,000 or more peasant insurgents.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="cm1907">{{ro icon}} [[Cătălin Mihuleac]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/MIHULEACapr7.html " '1907' și '1989' - două mari manipulări prin presă"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', April 2007</ref> Cocea himself eventually settled for a death toll of 12,000, claiming that, "had the peasants' bodies been lined up and down on [[Calea Victoriei]]", [[King of Romania|Romanian King]] [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I of Hohenzollern]] could have walked over to [[Dealul Mitropoliei]] "on a soft rug of peasant flesh".<ref name="cm1907"/>
During the actual events, N. D. Cocea was mainly active on the lower course of the [[Danube]], recognized by other socialists as "one of the leaders of the [workers'] movement" in [[Brăila]].<ref name="ctp184">Petrescu, p.184</ref> His regional daily, ''Dezrobirea'' ("The Emancipation"), was probably paid for by a local banker, Alphonse (or Alfons) Nachtigal.<ref name="stamoral2"/> Drawing official suspicion as a republican paper,<ref name="stamoral2"/> it became noted for fueling revolt regionally. After the ''România Muncitoare'' circle organized a socialist rally in Brăila, ''Dezrobirea''{{'}}s entire staff was arrested on orders from Prefect [[Nicolae T. Faranga]], who also confiscated most of the printed issues (although some 1,000 were still freely distributed among the intrigued peasants).<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.obiectivbr.ro/component/content/article/58-arhiva/11239-Braila%20fierbea%20inca%20din%201899.html "Brăila fierbea încă din 1899"], in ''[[Obiectiv-Vocea Brăilei]]'', March 20, 2007</ref> Cocea was eventually tried as an instigator, and sentenced to a term in prison.<ref>Cernat, p.29; Mitchievici, p.127; Petrescu, p.201</ref>
Upon his release, Cocea moved back to Bucharest, where he became a socialist orator, a ''România Muncitoare'' editor, and a correspondent of the workers' journal ''Viitorul Social''.<ref name="ctp184"/> He was one of the Romanian delegates to the [[International Socialist Congress, Stuttgart 1907|International Socialist Congress]], hosted by the [[Second International]] in [[Stuttgart]].<ref>Călinescu, p.919; Camboulives, p.184; Petrescu, p.202-203, 215, 411-412</ref> It was there that Russian socialist opinion leader [[Vladimir Lenin]] publicized a thesis according to which the Romanian revolt and the [[Russian Revolution of 1905]] were similar, in both character and impact.<ref name="cm1907"/> Back in Romania, Cocea was resuming his contacts with Dobrogeanu-Gherea, who was by then all but withdrawn from active socialist politics. As Cocea later wrote, the veteran leader confessed to him that he was being brought down by acute [[insomnia]].<ref>I. Felea, "Gherea și alții despre Gherea", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', December 1971, p.52</ref>
The young activist was blending his socialism with a critic's interest in [[modern art]] and [[experimental literature]]. Literary historian [[Paul Cernat]] argues that, like Symbolist poet [[N. Davidescu]], Cocea spent the 1900-1920 period disseminating [[modernist literature]] "on all fronts".<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.22</ref> He made his name as an art critic by 1908, when, like Arghezi, he defended the Romanian [[Post-Impressionism|post-Impressionist]] art club, whose members were being marginalized by the ''[[Tinerimea Artistică]]'' society; he also saluted [[Iosif Iser]]'s international post-Impressionist exhibit.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.46-47</ref> Within a series of articles in ''Pagini Libere'' journal, Cocea also explained his divorce with Symbolism and [[Art Nouveau]], concluding that they represented "the cosmopolitan class of sloth and of universal [[parasitism (social offense)|parasitism]]".<ref>Mitchievici, p.100-101</ref> The following year, Cocea was assigned the art column of ''[[Noua Revistă Română]]'', an eclectic journal put out by Romanian thinker [[Constantin Rădulescu-Motru]]. While there, he militated in favor of modernized art, urging artists to destroy "antiquated artistic formulas" and to subvert "the laws of nature".<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.8</ref>
===''Viața Socială''=== According to Cocea's future friend and foe [[Pamfil Șeicaru]], 1910 was the time year Cocea, with [[Christian Rakovsky]], [[Ecaterina Arbore]], [[I. C. Frimu]] and [[Ilie Moscovici]], was in the "chief of staff" of the newly created [[Social Democratic Party of Romania (1910-1918)|Social Democratic Party of Romania]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.curierulnational.ro/Specializat/2003-06-14/Social-democratia+romaneasca+fata+in+fata+cu+traditiile+ei "Social-democrația românească față în față cu tradițiile ei"], in ''[[Curierul Național]]'', June 14, 2003</ref> Cocea was additionally a member of the party's Social Studies Circle, furnishing its library and organizing its Kalinderu Church offices.<ref>Petrescu, p.218-219</ref>
In February 1910, Cocea and Arghezi set up a new periodical, ''[[Viața Socială]]''. The magazine, which received contributions from Dobrogeanu-Gherea, militated for [[universal suffrage]], [[social equality]] and [[Land reform in Romania|land reform]], while informing readers about world socialism.<ref>Vianu, p.479</ref> It enlisted collaborations from a number of [[anti-establishment]] journalists, from [[Agrarianism|agrarian]] militant [[Vasile Kogălniceanu]] and socialist physician [[Tatiana Grigorovici]] to writers [[Ion Minulescu]], [[Lucia Demetrius]] or [[Constantin Graur]], and republished contributions from some of Europe's known social critics: [[Eduard Bernstein]], [[Rinaldo Rigola]], [[Vsevolod Garshin]], [[Leo Tolstoy]], [[Jean Jaurès]], [[Emile Vandervelde]], [[Hubert Lagardelle]]<ref name="stamoral2"/> and [[Gustave Hervé]].<ref>Mitchievici, p.99</ref> Other contributors were Arbore, Davidescu, V. Demetrius, [[Traian Demetrescu]], [[Sofia Nădejde]], [[Vasile Savel]] and [[Avram Steuerman-Rodion]].<ref>Mitchievici, p.99, 126-127, 432</ref>
Culturally, this moment saw Cocea and his friends coordinating the transition from Symbolism to the early 20th-century avant-garde.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.23, 29-32</ref> This move was also accelerated by art critic [[Theodor Cornel]], who was for while a staff writer for Cocea's publication.<ref>[[Dan Grigorescu]], ''Istoria unei generații pierdute: expresioniștii'', [[Editura Eminescu]], Bucharest, 1980, p.430. {{OCLC|7463753}}</ref> In his first ''Viața Socială'' editorial, Cocea himself deemed Arghezi "the most revolutionary poet" of the period.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30; Michael H. Impey, "A Polemical Interpretation of Tudor Arghezi's 'Testament' ", in [[Keith Hitchins]] (ed.), ''Rumanian Studies. Vol. IV: 1976-1979'', [[Brill Publishers]], Leiden, 1979, p.196. {{ISBN|90-04-06003-0}}. See also Vianu, p.479-480</ref> However, his unilateral decision to publish Arghezi's "Evening Prayer", as an example of poetic rebellion,<ref>Vianu, p.479-480</ref> greatly enraged the expatriated author.<ref>Anghel, p.47</ref> They resumed their friendship only after Arghezi returned from his Swiss sojourn, and Cocea, with Galaction, [[Dumitru Karnabatt]] and various others, frequented the salon formed in Arghezi's Bucharest home.<ref>{{ro icon}} Vasile Man, [http://www.revista-studii-uvvg.ro/files/revista_V_2.pdf "Repere argheziene"], in the [[Vasile Goldiș West University of Arad]] ''Studii de Știință și Cultură'', Nr. 2 (17), June 2009, p.67</ref> Cocea was also witness when Arghezi wedded his long-term lover, Constanța Zissu (December 1912); the register describes him as "a journalist by profession, living at Polonă Street, 1."<ref>Popescu-Cadem, p.226-227</ref>
Through Galaction's interventions, ''Viața Socială'' maintained links with the more mainstream and home-grown current on Romania's leftist scene, [[Poporanism]], as well as with the post-socialist magazine of Iași, ''[[Viața Românească]]''.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.8, 30, 34. See also Călinescu, p.678</ref> It also published several poems by the young Poporanist [[George Topîrceanu]].<ref>Mitchievici, p.99; [[Al. Săndulescu]], chronological table and notes to [[George Topîrceanu]], ''Scrieri'', Vols. I, [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1983, p.XX, 307-308. {{OCLC|10998949}}</ref> Also in Iași, the ''Viața Socială'' circle acquired a number of young disciples, involved in editing ''Fronda'' and ''Absolutio'' magazines: [[Isac Ludo]], [[Eugen Relgis]] etc.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.55-57</ref>
Still, traditionalist critic [[Ilarie Chendi]] notes, ''Viața Socială'' as a whole failed, because the Symbolist and post-Symbolist contributors were not ardent socialists, and because no "notable poets or prose writers" could be found among the socialists.<ref name="icvieata">{{ro icon}} [[Ilarie Chendi]], [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/luceafarul/1912/BCUCLUJ_FP_280091_1912_011_003.pdf "Vieața literară în 1911 (o privire generală)"], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 3/1912, p.63 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> The same was observed in 1913 by critic Gheorghe Savul, who suggested that ''Viața Socială'' took on Symbolists such as Davidescu for opportunistic reasons, since they also had an anti-bourgeois axe to grind, but that there was little else to unite its contributors.<ref>Mitchievici, p.126-127</ref>
Cocea was by then frequenting the [[Anarchism|anarchist]] boyar [[Alexandru Bogdan-Pitești]], an art patron, cultural innovator and personal friend of Arghezi.<ref name="pc39">Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.39</ref> In 1911, he visited Italy together with Lagardelle, the French [[Syndicalism|Syndicalist]] militant, and personally met with liberal theorists [[Benedetto Croce]] and [[Guglielmo Ferrero]], as well as with Syndicalist [[Arturo Labriola]] and fellow journalist [[Giuseppe Prezzolini]].<ref name="gc919"/> His [[Travel writing|travel account]], which includes [[essay]]s on art and civilization, was published the same year, as ''Spre Roma'' ("Toward Rome").<ref>Călinescu, p.919, 1026</ref>
===''Rampa'' and ''Facla'' (first edition)=== Back in Romania, Cocea launched ''[[Rampa (Romanian magazine)|Rampa]]'', a theatrical review originally published as a daily. His partner in this venture was a veteran of thetrical life, [[Alexandru Davila]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Vera Molea, [http://www.bibliotecametropolitana.ro/Uploads/martie2009.pdf "Alexandru Davila și revolta studențească din 13 martie 1906"], in the Mihail Sadoveanu City Library ''Biblioteca Bucureștilor'', Nr. 3/2009, p.9</ref> Cocea also set up the independent socialist newspaper ''[[Facla]]''. The latter, identified as Romania's first socialist and satirical magazine by Arghezi himself,<ref name="marcs205">Anghel & Sfetea, p.205</ref> was soon joined by the 18-year-old poet [[Ion Vinea]], as literary columnist and campaigner for post-Symbolist literature,<ref name="isclasici">{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/patrimoniul_clasicilor_de_izbelite "Patrimoniul clasicilor de izbeliște?"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 33/2005</ref><ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30, 61-70, 74, 92-93, 140</ref> with painters Iser<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30; {{ro icon}} Boris Marian, [http://www.romanianjewish.org/db/pdf/nr252_253/pagina16.pdf "Un mare pictor: Iosif Iser"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 252-253 (1052-1053), May 2006, p.16</ref> and [[Camil Ressu]]<ref>{{ro icon}} Alina Ciufu, [http://www.telegrafonline.ro/pdf/pagini/1200866400/cultura.pdf "Picturile lui Camil Ressu, la Muzeul de Artă"], in ''[[Telegraf Constanța]]'', January 21, 2008, p.7</ref> as illustrators. The other noted contributors to Cocea's publications were [[Toma Dragu]], [[Saniel Grossman]],<ref name="marcs205"/> [[George Diamandy]],<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Florin Faifer]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/FAIFERap.html "Moșierul"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', April 2002</ref> [[Camil Petrescu]]<ref>Vianu, p.315</ref> and [[avant-garde]] critic [[Poldi Chapier]], whose 1912 article for ''Rampa'' chronicled the international success of [[Futurism]].<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.90</ref> Also featured were poems and translations by the post-Symbolist [[H. Bonciu]].<ref>Călinescu, p.900</ref> Cocea's own contributions include the chronicle of a play by [[Henry Bataille]]<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Dan Grigorescu]], [http://www.curierulnational.ro/Opinii/2004-03-13/Cultura+cotidiana "Cultura cotidiană"], in ''[[Curierul Național]]'', March 13, 2004</ref> and a salute to the "invincible spirit" of the [[5 October 1910 revolution|Portuguese republican revolution]].<ref>Ion Babici, "Octombrie 1910. Portugalia se proclamă republică", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', October 1975, p.40</ref>
Alongside renewed attacks on Romania's cultural traditionalism, Cocea and Arghezi initiated a lengthy campaign in favor of universal suffrage.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30</ref> Their articles and headlines were often [[Sensationalism|sensationalist]] and provoking, again focusing on Carol I, Romania's aging King. They often referred to the monarch as ''Ploșnița'' ("The Tick"), ''Gheșeftarul'' ("The Shop-Keeper") or ''Neamțul'' ("The Kraut").<ref name="gpproces">{{ro icon}} G. Pienescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/un_proces_care_nu_a_avut_loc_dect_pe_hrtie "Un proces care nu a avut loc decât pe hârtie"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 24/2006</ref> ''Facla'', with media support from ''Adevărul'' and the Romanian anarchist milieus, was taunting the authorities by staging its own mock trial for ''[[lèse majesté]]''.<ref name="gpproces"/> ''Facla''{{'}}s [[anticlericalism]], specifically aimed at the Orthodox Church, formed part of a larger scandal, which had earlier seen Arghezi giving up his [[hierodeacon]]'s frock.<ref>Anghel & Sfetea, p.205-206</ref> The ardent [[antimilitarism]] of Cocea's ''Facla'' articles, in particular his mockery of General [[Grigore C. Crăiniceanu]] and his sons, had similar results: the journalist was handed a preemptive and dishonorable [[military discharge]].<ref>Constantinescu, July 1971, p.21</ref>
Culturally, ''Facla'' was a leading adversary of traditionalist literature and of the [[Nationalism|nationalist]] periodicals which supported it. Its attack was concentrated on ''[[Drum Drept]]'' and ''[[Convorbiri Critice]]'' magazines (the focus of Vinea's articles)<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.63, 65</ref> and on [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] historian [[Nicolae Iorga]], who had earlier dismissed ''Facla'' as a venue for [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish Romanian]] interests.<ref>Anghel & Sfetea, p.210; {{ro icon}} Minodora Sălcudean, [http://www.revista-studii-uvvg.ro/files/revista_V_2.pdf "Discursul public arghezian. Strategii polemice în ''Scrisoarea deschisă''"], in the [[Vasile Goldiș West University of Arad]] ''Studii de Știință și Cultură'', Nr. 2 (17), June 2009, p.26, 28</ref> ''Facla'' also inaugurated the conflict between Cocea and the ''Viața Românească'' Poporanists. As a socialist, Cocea attacked the Poporanists for supporting artistic nationalism, and then for courting the mainstream [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]].<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30, 147</ref>
Cocea unsuccessfully presented himself as a Social Democratic candidate in the [[Romanian general election, 1912|elections of 1912]], the first ones in Romania to be contested by an independent socialist party.<ref>Petrescu, p.206</ref> However, he soon broke off from the party, and came to be considered a representative of the "bourgeois press" by his former socialist colleagues. One of them, [[Constantin Titel Petrescu]], informs that Cocea "could not live by the party discipline".<ref>Petrescu, p.257-258</ref>
===World War I, October Revolution and ''Chemarea''=== At an early stage in [[World War I]], public opinion in neutral Romania was divided between the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]] and the [[Central Powers]], both of which held Romanian [[irredenta]]. In this context, the [[Francophile]] Cocea manifested himself as an outspoken partisan of Romania's alliance with the Entente.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30; Camboulives, p.184</ref> There followed a split between Cocea and his erstwhile partners Arghezi, Galaction and Bogdan-Pitești. The latter three were committed [[Germanophile]]s who proceeded to publish their own review, ''Cronica''.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.23, 39-45, 98. See also Vianu, p.482-483</ref> ''[[Chemarea]]'', a mainly political magazine published by Ion Vinea in 1915, stood between the two groups, but was probably managed by Cocea, who allegedly came up with its name (lit. "the calling").<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.23</ref> Cocea's friendship with Arghezi had again soured to the point of mutual hatred. In ''Facla'', Cocea made thinly veiled comments about the poet's mother, an unmarried woman, and suggested that the ''Cronica'' staff "still lives on the morsels left over from Bogdan-Pitești's feasts".<ref>Popescu-Cadem, p.217</ref>
When the [[Romania during World War I|1916-1917 Campaign]] turned into a defensive war, N. D. Cocea joined the government and Land Forces on their retreat to [[Western Moldavia]].
