Reunited with Vinea, he helped publish a daily named ''Deșteptarea'' ("The Awakening"), flirting with the Germanophiles and [[Zimmerwald Conference|Zimmerwald neutralists]], hotly criticizing the Ententist and National Liberal establishment.<ref name="gsfrondistul">{{ro icon}} [[Geo Șerban]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Un-profil-Jacques-Frondistul*articleID_6309-articles_details.html "Un profil: Jacques Frondistul"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 144, November 2002</ref><ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.98-99</ref> However, he remained an outspoken critic of those public figures whom he perceived as German hirelings, including politician [[Alexandru Marghiloman]] and ''Arena'' newspaperman [[Alfred Hefter-Hidalgo]].<ref name="gsfrondistul"/> As was later acknowledged by Vinea, Cocea and his ''Deșteptarea'' colleagues had formed a conspiratorial "revolutionary republican committee".<ref name="ivdumitriu">{{ro icon}} [[Ion Vartic]], [http://www.romlit.ro/petru_dumitriu_i_negrul_su_ii "Petru Dumitriu și 'negrul' său" (II)], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 16/2005</ref> Both of them were also affiliated with a wing of the [[Freemasonry in Romania|Romanian Freemasonry]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Fabian Anton, [http://193.26.10.83/pdf/Ararat%2007%202007.pdf "Armenii în masoneria românească"], in ''[http://193.26.10.83/ Ararat]'', Nr. 7/2007, p.6</ref><ref name="msmessage">Marcel Shapira, [http://www.masonicforum.ro/archive/en/nr20/schapira.html "Message"], in the National Grand Lodge of Romania ''[http://www.masonicforum.ro/ Masonic Forum Magazine]'', Winter 2005</ref>
A while after, Cocea made his way in the [[Russian Provisional Government|Russian Republic]], Romania's Entente ally, and settled in [[Petrograd]]. His activities there included putting out the [[French-language]] magazine, ''L'Entente'' ("The Entente"), which was financed by his old rivals, the Romanian National Liberals.<ref>Rusu Abrudeanu, p.119-120; See also Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.30</ref> As a resident of [[Hotel Astoria (Saint Petersburg)|Hotel Astoria]],<ref>Baciu, p.7</ref> he witnessed first-hand the [[October Revolution]], and became a passionate supporter of the [[Bolshevik]] cause. He later claimed to have been present, on Revolution day, in the [[Petrograd Soviet]] hall, hearing the victorious speech of Bolshevik leader [[Vladimir Lenin]],<ref>Baciu, p.6, 8</ref> and to have later attended the second [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets]].<ref name="vf147">Frunză, p.147</ref><ref name="mseisenstein">{{ro icon}} Marius Șopterean, [http://www.revistatribuna.ro/doc_db_site/tribuna/tribuna84.pdf "1001 de filme și nopți. 13: Eisenstein"], in ''[[Tribuna (Romania)|Tribuna]]'', Nr. 84/2006, p.35</ref> As a representative of the International Association for Information of the Labor Press of America, France, and [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain]], Cocea exchanged notes with Lenin. He interviewed Lenin about the Bolsheviks' goals, assuring him that his replies would be published verbatim.<ref>Baciu, p.7; [[Vladimir Lenin]], ''[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1917/nov/10b.htm To: The International Association for Information of the Labour Press of America, France, and Great Britain]'', at the [[Marxists Internet Archive]] (retrieved February 14, 2011)</ref>
By the end of the year, Cocea had returned to Moldavia. Under his direction (December 1917 to February 1918), ''Deșteptarea'' became a new edition of ''Chemarea''. It was often issued with large blank spaces, showing interventions by military censors.<ref name="gsfrondistul"/> The gazette managed to publish a letter of protest, signed by poet [[Benjamin Fondane]], expressing a hope that Arghezi would not be prosecuted as a traitor.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.139</ref> After advertising its "radical socialist" agenda, ''Chemarea'' was promptly shut down by the [[Alexandru Averescu]] cabinet.<ref name="pc99">Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.99</ref> For this and other reasons, Cocea would later refer to Averescu as the organizer of "[[White Terror (Russia)|White Terror]]" in Romania.<ref name="icaug41">Constantinescu, August 1971, p.41</ref>
Cocea was a strong critic of Romania's [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|separate armistice with Germany]],<ref name="gsfrondistul"/> and consequently listed as a ''[[persona non grata]]'' by the Central Powers.<ref>Rusu Abrudeanu, p.368-371</ref> In August 1918, he launched ''Depeșa'' ("The Dispatch"), later published as a third edition of ''Chemarea''. A new presence on these two periodicals was writer [[Jacques G. Costin]], who produced several political pieces (including a renewed denunciation of Hefter-Hidalgo) and later the musical chronicle.<ref name="gsfrondistul"/><ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.188</ref> Its other staff writers were young men who later built career in the political press, both left- and right-wing: Vinea, [[Demostene Botez]], [[Alexandru Busuioceanu]], [[Cezar Petrescu]], [[Pamfil Șeicaru]]<ref name="gsfrondistul"/> and [[Adrian Maniu]].<ref name="stamoral2"/> They took care of the newspaper when Cocea left Iași on a short visit to [[Bessarabia]], a former Russian province that was in the process of [[Union of Bessarabia with Romania|uniting with Romania]].<ref name="gsfrondistul"/>
Victorious in its lengthy conflict with Hefter's ''Arena'', ''Chemarea'' eventually relocated to Bucharest, but suffered from the nationwide paper shortage.<ref name="gsfrondistul"/> Cocea supported the [[Socialist Party of Romania]] (PS) through the leftist riots of December 1918, and, when the PS leadership was arrested, sat on the defense team, alongside Mille and Dragu.<ref>Petrescu, p.320-321</ref>
''Chemarea'' survived until November 1, 1919—when its lampoon of Romanian King [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand I]] prompted the intervention of military censors.<ref name="pc99"/> On November 2, shortly before the [[Romanian general election, 1919|general election day]], Cocea profited from the temporary suspension of censorship to reissue the same paper, subsequently renamed ''Chemarea Roșie'' ("The Red Call"), then ''Facla'', ''Torța'' ("The Torch"), ''Clopotul'' ("The Bell") and again ''Chemarea'' (changes which were supposed to keep censors always a step behind Cocea).<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.99, 132, 140, 188</ref> These publications were attempts to revive and radicalize the socialist literary press, that had virtually succumbed in Romania after the demise of ''Facla''{{'}}s first edition. A [[Marxism|Marxist]] literary critic, [[Ovid Crohmălniceanu]], proposes that Cocea's renewed offensive missed the mark, lacking "a clear enough vision".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.144-145</ref>
===Parliamentary mandate=== Cocea was elected to the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Lower Chamber]] during the November 1919 suffrage (reelected during the [[Romanian general election, 1920|May 1920 suffrage]]). He represented a non-partisan [[electoral list]] for Bucharest (the Citizen's List), whose other two candidates, physician [[Nicolae L. Lupu]] and lawyer [[Constantin Costa-Foru]], also won seats.<ref>Constantinescu, July 1971, p.20</ref> Although officially an independent, he rallied with the PS in the Chamber minority group led by [[Gheorghe Cristescu]] and [[Ilie Moscovici]].<ref>Filipescu, p.67-69. See also Constantinescu, ''passim''</ref> Cocea's mandate was immediately contested by his National Liberal adversaries. They sought to invalidate his candidature, citing a law which prevented those with a military discharge from running in elections. The National Liberal motion was however defeated when Cocea, who presented himself as a political victim, earned unexpected support from the [[Romanian National Party]] and the [[Democratic Nationalist Party (Romania)|Democratic Nationalist Party]].<ref>Constantinescu, July 1971, p.21-22</ref>
In opposition to the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's Party]] and the [[anti-communist]] consensus, Cocea spoke positively in [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] about [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]], arguing that the Bolshevik foreign policy had saved the whole of civilization, and citing favorable statements made by the returning war prisoners.<ref>Filipescu, p.67-68, 71, 73</ref> His theory was that the [[Comintern]] was a legitimate successor of the [[First International]]. The notion was contested by another socialist deputy, Dragu—early signs of a schism between the Cominternist socialist-communists and those who followed the [[International Working Union of Socialist Parties|Vienna International]].<ref>Filipescu, p.69-70</ref> In one of his addresses to the Chamber (July 28, 1920), Cocea presented a vision of socialism that was neither "unilateral" nor "narrow", but suited to the needs of "all peoples and all times", and quoted from ''[[The Internationale]]''.<ref>Potop, p.42</ref> Cocea's rhetoric, equating the October Revolution with the [[Virgin birth of Jesus|birth of Christ]] and glorifying the [[Slavic soul]], was ridiculed from the benches as "Russian mysticism".<ref>Filipescu, p.68</ref>
For a while, Cocea's sympathy turned toward the rising [[Peasants' Party (Romania)|Peasants' Party]]. This Poporanist group, which reacted against National Liberal politics and sought peace with the socialists and the Soviets, was called "civilized and [[Westernization|Westernized]]" by the socialist journalist.<ref>Filipescu, p.71</ref> Nevertheless, Cocea was becoming disappointed by the [[parliamentary system]] of [[Greater Romania]]. He argued that Parliament itself should be replaced with a [[Technocracy|technocratic]] body, elected by a radical form of [[universal suffrage]],<ref>Filipescu, p.69</ref> and clamored his belief that "in short while, [...] Romania will be socialist."<ref name="icaug41"/>
In August 1920, Cocea voted in favor of [[Grigore Trancu-Iași]]'s labor law, although he found it unsatisfactory—his stated belief was that the law's inequities would spark a "[[social revolution]]".<ref>Filipescu, p.75</ref> There followed the [[1920 Romanian general strike|October 1920 general strike]], that was condoned and supported by Cocea and the writers at ''Chemarea''.<ref>Ion Iacoș, "Contribuții privind greva generală din octombrie 1920", in ''Studii. Revistă de Istorie'', Nr. 6/1970, p.1077, 1078, 1079, 1087</ref> During December, following a [[state of siege]], Cocea and Lupu were behind parliamentary efforts to investigate the alleged murder of socialist activist [[Herșcu Aroneanu]] by People's Party authorities.<ref>Constantinescu, August 1971, p.42-43</ref>
When, in early 1921, Cristescu and the other socialist-communists set up the [[Romanian Communist Party]] (PCR), Cocea became an outside sympathizer of their cause, protesting against their imprisonment and prosecution in the [[Dealul Spirii Trial]].<ref>Constantinescu, September 1971, p.70-71; Potop, p.42-43</ref> In May and June of that year, when Chamber was assessing the case of Moscovici's seat, left vacant by his sentencing after the strike, Cocea asked for it to be filled by [[Constantin Popovici (politician)|Constantin Popovici]]; Popovici, next on the electoral list, was himself under arrest.<ref>Constantinescu, September 1971, p.70</ref> His speech about "government terror" ended in a heated dispute with People's Party deputies Berlescu (whom Cocea called a descendant of [[Roma minority in Romania|Romani]] [[Slavery in Romania|slaves]]) and Alexandru Oteteleșeanu.<ref>Constantinescu, September 1971, p.70-71</ref> Shortly before the [[Romanian general election, 1921|1921 suffrage]], Cocea labeled [[Conservative-Democratic Party|Conservative-Democratic]] leader [[Take Ionescu]], the [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]]-designate, as a pawn of King Ferdinand and his "[[camarilla]]".<ref>Constantinescu, September 1971, p.71</ref> Early in 1922, Cocea also joined [[Dem. I. Dobrescu]] and other lawyers on the Dealul Spirii Trial defense team.<ref>Ciorianu, p.29</ref>
===''Facla'' revival and 1923 trial=== [[File:Cum sunt decapitați regii cari se împotrivesc voinței poporului..., Facla 24 martie 1923.jpg|thumb|270px|''[[Facla]]'' of March 24, 1923, published with the warning ''Cum sunt decapitați regii cari se împotrivesc voinței poporului...'' ("How they decapitate kings who oppose the people's wishes...") alongside the [[execution of Louis XVI]]]] In 1920, ''Chemarea'' came to its end, and Cocea began putting out another edition of ''Facla'' weekly.<ref name="pc99"/> The newspaper acquired offices in the Frascatti Hotel (later the "Savoy" branch of [[Constantin Tănase Revue Theater]]), redecorated by artist [[Marcel Janco]].<ref name="sc46-47">Callimachi, p.46-47</ref> According to political scientist [[Stelian Tănase]], this enterprise was secretly financed by Soviet Russia as external [[agitprop]]: notes kept by ''[[Siguranța Statului]]'' intelligence agency suggest that Cocea was a regular guest at the [[Russian Ambassador to Romania|Russian mission in Romania]].<ref name="stamoral1"/>
Cocea's disciple, Ion Vinea, went on to publish the magazine ''[[Contimporanul]]'', originally as a socialist tribune, but later as a modernist forum.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.131-145, 220; Crohmălniceanu, p.59</ref> Cocea was an occasional contributor to this venue, but was separated from its [[avant-garde]] staff writers, having a less rebellious writing style and a more structured political vision.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.140, 194; Crohmălniceanu, p.65</ref> In exchange, Vinea was an occasional contributor to ''Facla'', whenever ''Contimporanul'' met financial difficulties;<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.135, 140, 212</ref> he was also the editorial director from 1925 to 1926 (the year when ''Facla'' again closed down).<ref name="isclasici"/><ref name="isserviciul">{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/un_poet_n_serviciul_gazetriei "Un poet în serviciul gazetăriei"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 34/2005</ref> Vinea's own political articles were noted for their critique of National Liberal policies, portraying liberal Romania as a [[Brătianu family]] dictatorship and campaigning in favor of the socialist groups.<ref name="isserviciul"/><ref name="pcrisipitor">{{ro icon}} [[Paul Cernat]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Publicistica-unui-constructivist-risipitor*articleID_9408-articles_details.html "Publicistica unui constructivist risipitor"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 191, October 2003</ref> Around 1924, the ''Facla'' group was also joined by "Red Prince" [[Scarlat Callimachi]], a modernist promoter and communist militant,<ref name="sc46-47"/> by aspiring critic [[Șerban Cioculescu]],<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Al. Săndulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/mnctorulde_cri "Mâncătorul de cărți"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 11/2008</ref> and by the [[Zionism|Zionist]] opinion maker [[A. A. Luca]].<ref name="lbdioptr">{{ro icon}} [[Liviu Bordaș]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Altfel-despre-dioptriile-lui-Mircea-Eliade-%28II%29*articleID_21235-articles_details.html "Altfel despre dioptriile lui Mircea Eliade" (II)], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 461, February 2009</ref> Cocea was at the time the animator of cultural debates at [[Terasa Oteteleșanu]], where he introduced the young novelist and journalist [[I. Peltz]].<ref name="aspeltz">{{ro icon}} [[Al. Săndulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/i._peltz_memorialist "I. Peltz memorialist"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 35/2004</ref><ref>{{ro icon}} Simona Vasilache, [http://www.romlit.ro/cu_voi.. "Cu voi..."], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 27/2006</ref>
The early 1920s also witnessed N. D. Cocea's involvement in various other civic and cultural campaigns. He became, in 1922, a member of the Romanian [[Friends of Nature]], a socialist-inspired [[environmental organization]], and, the following year, joined Dem I. Dobrescu in creating the League for Human Rights.<ref name="ac135">Cioroianu, p.135</ref> He was among the regular guests at [[International Red Aid]] "literary tea parties", described by historian [[Adrian Cioroianu]] as "one of those schemes the communists employed in collecting money for their comrades in prison".<ref name="ac135"/> With Fondane, director [[Armand Pascal]] and various others, Cocea also participated in creating ''Insula'', an actors' working group. It was supposed to revolutionize [[Theatre of Romania|Romanian theater]], but disappeared after only a few months of existence (February 1923).<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.271-273</ref> Cocea compensated by giving moral support to the Jewish modernist [[Vilna Troupe]], which relocated to Bucharest in 1924.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.277</ref> Also that year Cocea published a new book, ''Ignoranță'' ("Ignorance").<ref name="gc1026">Călinescu, p.1026</ref>
After the adoption by a National Liberal legislature of Romania's [[1923 Constitution of Romania|1923 Constitution]], Cocea joined up with the angrier ranks of political opposition. He soon publicized a claim that King Ferdinand and his favorite minister, Brătianu, had together given legal foundations to a [[plutocracy]].<ref name="pc140">Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.140</ref> He was taken to court and lost, being sentenced for ''[[lèse majesté]]''.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="stamoral2"/><ref name="pc140"/> Reputedly, the authorities also confiscated samples of Cocea's anticlerical fiction works, but these were recovered and published by ''Contimporanul'' in 1925.<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.169</ref> Through the voice of Vinea, ''Contimporanul'' also protested the sentencing, claiming that Cocea was a persecuted man, his career "a spectacle of modern dramatism".<ref name="pc140"/> The trial attracted significant attention among the Romanian youth, which divided itself into monarchists and republicans.<ref name="lbdioptr"/>
Cocea's conduct was the topic of controversy throughout the early 1920s: in 1922, Cocea's influential modernist rival, the literary theorist [[Eugen Lovinescu]], bitterly attacked him, Arghezi and Bogdan-Pitești for their wartime conduct.<ref name="pc39"/> Noted for its [[Xenophobia|xenophobic]] attacks on ''Contimporanul''{{'}}s editors,<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.207</ref> the nationalist review ''[[Țara Noastră]]'' openly celebrated Cocea's arrest. An unsigned note in that paper announced that Cocea had been imprisoned "for the least of his crimes", and called to mind that Cocea had been lampooning its editor, [[Octavian Goga]].<ref name="tninsemnari">{{ro icon}} [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/9738/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_451581_1923_004_041.pdf "Însemnări"], in ''[[Țara Noastră]]'', Nr. 41/1923, p.1326 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> The antisemitic publicist [[Ion Gorun|Alexandru Hodoș]] designated Cocea's supporters at ''Adevărul'' and ''[[Cuvântul Liber (1924)|Cuvântul Liber]]'' with the title of "[[Shabbos goy]]im", describing Cocea as a habitual prankster, a renegade of the socialist cause, and a dishonorable man.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Gorun|Alexandru Hodoș]], [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/9755/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_451581_1924_005_030.pdf "Adulatori și pamfletari"], in ''[[Țara Noastră]]'', Nr. 30/1924, p.942-944 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
Cocea served his sentence of one year and a half at [[Craiova]] penitentiary, and paid the 10,000 [[Romanian leu|lei]] fine.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="stamoral2"/> He was afterward involved in communist agitation, speaking at PCR rallies in [[Câmpina]] (1925), [[Soroca]] and [[Otaci]] (during the [[Romanian general election, 1931|1931 electoral campaign]]).<ref name="stamoral2"/> The PCR underground's leaders were often Cocea's guests at Frascatti.<ref>Callimachi, p.47</ref> His modernist supporters did not follow his lead. By 1929, Vinea and ''Contimporanul'' were toning down their own socialist agenda, cooperating instead with the moderate [[National Peasants' Party]], and even drawing suspicion from the left that they had become sympathetic to [[fascism]].<ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.169-179, 229-244</ref> Generally a critic of the National Peasantists,<ref name="gc919"/> Cocea quit a resurfacing ''Facla'' in 1930, leaving Vinea in charge (the latter was editor of that newspaper until its 1940 disestablishment).<ref name="isclasici"/><ref name="isserviciul"/>
===1930s novels and ''Era Nouă''=== Over the next few years, N. D. Cocea is believed to have been largely inactive in the political press.<ref name="pastia289">Pastia, p.289</ref> Instead, he made his return to fiction. In 1931, his novel ''Vinul de viață lungă'' ("The Wine of a Long Life") was released under contract with [[Editura Cultura Națională]].<ref name="gc1026"/> Its received much acclaim, unmatched by Cocea's later works in the genre, which critics often found unpalatable for their [[Erotic literature|erotic content]].<ref>Camboulives, p.184. See also Călinescu, p.919; Pastia, ''passim''</ref> Cocea's erotic series includes: ''Fecior de slugă'' ("The Son of the Servant"), published in 1933 by Cultura Națională; ''Pentr-un petec de negreață'' ("Over a Black Patch", also known as ''Andrei Vaia''), 1934, [[Editura Librăriei Leon Alcaly|Alcaly Publishers]]; and ''Nea Nae'' ("Uncle Nae"), 1935, Alcaly.<ref name="gc1026"/>
During that interval, Cocea was again brought into custody. He was tried and imprisoned for [[statutory rape]], having eloped with the 16-year-old Gina, orphaned daughter of the wealthy National Liberal politico [[Ion Manolescu-Strunga]].<ref name="stamoral1"/> The liberties he took in public life, and the provoking nature of his writings, resulted in other disputes with the nationalists, forming part of their larger conservative crusade against "[[pornography]]" and the avant-garde. The traditionalist periodical ''[[Neamul Românesc]]'', put out by [[Nicolae Iorga]], had "Cocea Niculae" on its [[blacklist]], as the third most offensive Romanian author (the avant-garde authors [[H. Bonciu]] and [[Geo Bogza]] were at No. 1 and No. 2 respectively).<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Gheorghe Grigurcu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/despre_pornografie_ii "Despre pornografie" (II)], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 3/2007</ref> In parallel, Cocea was becoming involved in a publicized controversy with his wartime colleague [[Pamfil Șeicaru]]. As commentators have since noted, the two journalists were equally vulgar, but Șeicaru had been enlisted by the nationalists and the traditionalists.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="nmmoralitati">{{ro icon}} [[Nicolae Manolescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/moraliti "Moralități"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 11/2000</ref>
In 1934, Cocea joined a group known as ''[[Amicii URSS]]'', formed on the basis of a PCR initiative and formally seeking to normalize Romania's relations with the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>Callimachi, p.49; Cioroianu, p.114-115, 135</ref> In November of that year, ''[[Siguranța Statului]]'' was reporting that Cocea and Callimachi, together with [[Petre Constantinescu-Iași]], were going to establish in Bucharest a "far left platform" with a "pronounced [[Philosemitism|Semitic]] tendency"; known as ''Ideea Socială'' ("The Social Idea"), it was supposedly part of the ''[[Adevărul]]''-''[[Dimineața]]'' network.<ref name="stprintul">{{ro icon}} [[Stelian Tănase]], [http://www.sferapoliticii.ro/sfera/135/art07-arhiva.html " 'Prințul Roșu' "], in ''[[Sfera Politicii]]'', Nr. 135</ref> The period also brought Cocea's brief and uneventful marriage with Lila Stănescu. She was in reality the lover of PCR activist [[Ion Gheorghe Maurer]], whom the journalist continued to view as his friend.<ref name="ssscandaluri"/>
In 1936, the year when he married his long-time lover Gina Manolescu-Strunga,<ref name="ssscandaluri"/><ref name="gc919"/> Cocea again returned to the forefront of Romania's left-wing press, launching the theoretical magazine ''Era Nouă'' ("New Era"). Also a front for the PCR, replacing the banned ''[[Bluze Albastre]]'' of communist writer [[Alexandru Sahia]], ''Era Nouă'' was itself shut down by the authorities in 1937.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.151-152</ref> It had published only two issues. In one of its internal memos, ''Siguranța Statului'' reviewed the first of these as inoffensively "academic", the second as "agitatorial".<ref name="stamoral2"/> ''Siguranța'' agents also noted that Cocea, with Dobrescu and Callimachi, was making efforts to assist the PCR activists tried in [[Chișinău]], and trying to obtain further support from the left-wing National Peasantists ([[Virgil Madgearu]], [[Grigore Iunian]]).<ref name="stprintul"/>
''Era Nouă''{{'}}s main contributors were young communist essayists such as Sahia, [[Miron Radu Paraschivescu]], [[Ștefan Voicu]] and [[Silvian Iosifescu]], but the magazine also published avant-garde authors with [[Marxism|Marxist]] sensibilities: [[Ion Călugăru]], [[Stephan Roll]], [[Virgil Teodorescu]], [[Dolfi Trost]]<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.152-156</ref> and [[Paul Păun]].<ref name="viionescu">{{ro icon}} [[Virgil Ierunca]], [http://www.memoria.ro/marturii/domenii/diverse/diagonale_-_amintiri_despre_ghita_ionescu/1178/ "Diagonale - Amintiri despre Ghiță Ionescu"], at the [http://www.memoria.ro/ Memoria Digital Library]; retrieved July 17, 2014</ref> They were joined by communist polemicists [[Ghiță Ionescu]] and [[Belu Zilber]].<ref name="viionescu"/> In its first issue, ''Era Nouă'' prophesied that the [[Crisis (Marxian)|general crisis]] of [[capitalism]] was evident in the rapid decay of "its culture and ideology", leaving the [[proletariat]] in a position to reinterpret mainstream culture "on the large basis offered by [[dialectical materialism]]".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.152. See also Ornea, p.38</ref> According to cultural historian [[Zigu Ornea]], such pronouncements, soon taken up by the entire communist press, were in reality a form of left-wing [[totalitarianism]], and therefore equivalent to the internal logic of fascism.<ref>Ornea, p.37-41</ref>
===''Reporter'' magazine and tensions with the PCR=== Cocea was reputedly pondering the relaunch of ''Chemarea'' as a communist newspaper, supposedly with [[Ștefan Foriș]], the ex-convict head of PCR Agitprop, as its manager, and Paraschivescu, Voicu, as well as other [[Union of Communist Youth|Communist Youth]] activists, as co-editors.<ref name="stamoral2"/> ''Siguranța'' men had it that Cocea shocked his communist partners by informing them that ''Chemarea'' was to be a "[[Centrism|centrist]]" platform, with no known communist on its staff.<ref name="stamoral2"/> However, the senior socialist remained active in proximity to the PCR over the next year. In May 1937, he caught ''Siguranța''{{'}}s attention as a would-be collaborator to Callimachi's [[anti-fascist]] review ''Munca'' ("The Labor"). Making overtures toward the National Peasantist left-wingers, ''Munca'' also received contributions from poets [[Mihail Cruceanu]] and [[Sandu Tudor]], from sociologist [[Mihai Ralea]] and journalist [[Tudor Teodorescu-Braniște]], and from writer-director [[Sandu Eliad]].<ref name="stprintul"/> In summer 1937, the moderate left-wing ''[[Azi (Romanian newspaper)|Azi]]'' daily published Cocea's renewed criticism of censorship, part of a series of a collective reply to the [[far right]]'s moralistic discourse.<ref>Ornea, p.455</ref>
Cocea was again mandated by the PCR to lead ''Reporter'' weekly, beginning with its November 1937 issue. The periodical, already in existence for five years, was making efforts to reach the apolitical public.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.152, 156</ref> In an editorial for ''Reporter'', Cocea made comments similar to the ''Era Nouă'' program, with a more pronounced satirical tone and allusions to fascism: "however massive the stupidity of dictatorial rules, man's intelligence, honesty in convictions [and] the fervor of the masses will in the end topple them. [...] The greedy [[satrap]]s, the leeward adventurers have come to tumble down, one on top of the other."<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.156</ref>
''Reporter''{{'}}s agenda was generically anti-fascist: campaigning for the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republican side]] in the [[Spanish Civil War]], it lampooned [[Benito Mussolini]] and [[Adolf Hitler]], and repeatedly attacked the [[Iron Guard]] or other Romanian fascist groups.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.156-158</ref> Its political panelists included, alongside Voicu, Paraschivescu and Călugăru, the future communist historian [[Ion Popescu-Puțuri]], reporter [[Aurel Baranga]],<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.157-159</ref> and anti-fascist poet [[Gherasim Luca]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/engels_i_lautramont "Engels și Lautréamont"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 34/2003</ref> Other members of the ''Reporter'' circle, whose contacts with Cocea were closely investigated by the authorities, included a diverse gathering of PCR figures: Foriș, Trost, Marxist sociologist [[Lucrețiu Pătrășcanu]], unionist [[Ilie Pintilie]]<ref name="stamoral1"/> and the [[Bessarabia]]n poet [[Emilian Bucov]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Serafim Saka]], [http://www.sud-est.md/numere/20080915/article_8/ "Atunci – Partidul; acum – gașca"], in ''[[Revista Sud-Est]]'', Nr.3/2008</ref> ''Reporter'' also published the militant poems of [[Demostene Botez]], [[Liviu Deleanu]] and [[Al. Șahighian]], and samples of international left-leaning literature ([[Ilya Ehrenburg]], [[André Malraux]], [[Nikolai Ostrovsky]]).<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.158</ref> The maverick dramatist [[Mihail Sebastian]] was, for a while, ''Reporter''{{'}}s literary chronicler.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.159</ref>
Only two months after Cocea took over, ''Reporter'' was banned by state censorship, suspected of "communist tendencies" and of publishing "alarmist articles."<ref name="stamoral1"/> The sincerity of Cocea's political credo was by then coming into question: the maverick communist [[Petre Pandrea]] alleged that Cocea was infiltrated into the party ranks by ''Siguranța Statului''.<ref name="aspeltz"/> Stelian Tănase also describes Cocea as a [[double agent]], notoriously close to ''Siguranța'' director [[Mihail Moruzov]] (his Bucharest neighbor), trafficking in information from the communist movement and the court of [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]], but still advising PCR Agitprop.<ref name="stamoral1"/> Cocea was nevertheless being closely watched by the ''Siguranța'' Detective Corps. It kept notes on his meetings with French press correspondents, with Spanish Republican diplomats and with disgraced [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish Romanian]] journalists such as [[Jacques G. Costin]].<ref name="stamoral1"/> According to these documents, Cocea discussed political matters with the opponents of Carol II, including National Peasantist [[Iuliu Maniu]] and communist sympathizer [[Petru Groza]].<ref name="stamoral1"/> He is known to have had great sympathy for Maniu, despite their political differences.<ref name="mpîntâlniri">{{ro icon}} Marin Pop, [http://www.caietesilvane.ro/indexcs.php?cmd=articol&idart=1954 "Întâlniri secrete între Iuliu Maniu, Nicolae D. Cocea și Mihail Ralea (1942–1944)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714162339/http://www.caietesilvane.ro/indexcs.php?cmd=articol&idart=1954 |date=2014-07-14 }}, in ''Caiete Silvane'', Nr. 2/2013</ref>
===World War II=== A 1939 entry in Cocea's own diary admits that the "unexpected" [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Non-Aggression Treaty]] between the Soviets and [[Nazi Germany]] was the source of "doubting" and "bitterness" among left-wing Romanians, but scolds his old friend [[Nicolae L. Lupu]] for having then lost faith in socialism.<ref name="giflupu">{{ro icon}} Gheorghe I. Florescu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/FLORESCUdec6.html "Un socialist sui-generis: dr. N. Lupu"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', December 2006</ref> In contrast to his earlier political stances, Cocea was, by 1938, a member of the National Liberal Party, probably because a new wave of repression had led the PCR to implode.<ref name="vf147, 213-214">Frunză, p.147, 213-214</ref> He was registered with the National Liberals until after Carol II's [[National Renaissance Front]] dictatorship pushed them into semi-clandestinity, and still enjoyed a privileged relationship with them during [[World War II]].<ref name="vf147, 213-214"/>
Cocea was inactive during the war, when Romania was allied with the [[Axis Powers]], and the [[Romania during World War II|successive dictatorial regimes]]. Inhabiting a private villa in the [[Transylvania]]n town of [[Sighișoara]], he kept diaries which offer insight into his various political dealings.<ref name="stamoral1"/> Around 1939, he was separated from his wife Gina, following a series of disagreements in the family.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="ssscandaluri"/> The fascist [[National Legionary State|National Legionary regime]] continued to keep track on his movements during 1940, alarmed by rumors that he had been operating a clandestine [[printing press]], but was unable to determine whether he was still a communist.<ref name="stamoral1"/>
From 1941, the Nazi-aligned regime of ''[[Conducător]]'' [[Ion Antonescu]] ordered Romania's participation in the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|war against the Soviet Union]]. Cocea was active in the informal opposition to Antonescu, approaching his old friends in the mainstream political parties. As early as January 1942, Cocea met with the National Peasantist leadership, probing its attitude toward the Soviet Union and the Romanian communists. Like them, Cocea was positively impressed that the PCR was turning into a "patriotic" party and going back on its pro-German stance.<ref name="mpîntâlniri"/> Around 1944, Cocea resumed contacts with the since-revived PCR. In June, ''Siguranța'' reported that he was rounding up support for communist sympathizer [[Mihai Ralea]] and his underground [[Socialist Peasants' Party]].<ref name="stprintul"/> He later served as the communists' liaison with the National Liberal Party wing of [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]] (later, the [[National Liberal Party-Tătărescu]]). Cocea's intervention contributed to a strategic alliance between the communists and the various other parties, within a coalition which overthrew Antonescu (''see [[King Michael's Coup]]'').<ref name="vf147"/> Cocea's actress sister [[Alice Cocéa|Alice]], who was living in [[German occupation of France during World War II|Nazi-occupied France]], was taking a different path: she and her manager, Robert Capgras, had a friendly relationship with the Germans and were later deemed [[Collaboration with the Axis Powers during World War II|collaborators with the enemy]].<ref name="mdsalice"/><ref>Kenneth Krauss, ''The Drama of Fallen France: Reading'' La comédie sans Tickets, [[State University of New York Press]], Albany, 2004, p.8. {{ISBN|0-7914-5953-5}}</ref>
===Communist honors=== In September 1944, Cocea was elected Vice President of the [[Romanian Writers' Society]], which was in the process of expelling writers associated with the wartime regimes.<ref name="vdssr">{{ro icon}} Victor Durnea, [http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/articol.php?cod=9830 "Societatea scriitorilor români"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218133843/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/articol.php?cod=9830 |date=2012-02-18 }}, in ''[[Dacia Literară]]'', Nr. 2/2008 (republished by the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/ România Culturală] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902021335/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/ |date=2011-09-02 }}'')</ref><ref name="cv79">Cristian Vasile, ''Literatura și artele în România comunistă. 1948-1953'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 2010, p.79. {{ISBN|978-973-50-2773-5}}</ref> He personally proposed for some 50 "valuable writers", from [[Maria Banuș]] and [[Ury Benador]] to [[Radu Tudoran]] and [[Gheorghe Zane]], including many of his left-wing friends, to be admitted into the Society (only 20 of them were eventually received).<ref name="vdssr"/> The following month, he participated with Callimachi in the creation of a formally unified [[Union of Professional Journalists in Romania|Journalists' Trade Union]]. Split between PCR and National Peasantist lobbies, it was created around the conjectural goal of purging the Romanian press of fascist influences.<ref>Frunză, p.254-255</ref> The Union was originally presided by a Committee comprising Cocea, Callimachi, [[Nicolae Carandino]], [[Miron Constantinescu]], [[George Ivașcu]], [[Eugen Jebeleanu]], [[Octav Livezeanu]], [[George Macovescu]], [[Nicolae Moraru]], [[Ion Pas]], [[Grigore Preoteasa]], [[Tudor Teodorescu-Braniște]], [[Alfons Vogel]] and several others.<ref>Frunză, p.255</ref> In May 1945, Cocea represented the Writers' Society at the funeral of his ''Reporter'' colleague [[Mihail Sebastian]], who had been killed in a road accident.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.romanianjewish.org/db/pdf/nr275_276/speciala3.pdf "Din registrul 'faptelor diverse' în 'dosarele istoriei' "], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 275-276 (1075-1076), May 2007, p.III</ref>
The [[Romanian Society for Friendship with the Soviet Union]] (ARLUS), which offered a good reception to [[Soviet occupation of Romania|Soviet occupation forces]], counted N. D. and Dina Cocea among its earliest members (although they were probably not among its founders); in December 1944, father and daughter were co-opted on the ARLUS Leadership Committee.<ref>Cioroianu, p.120, 124</ref> The ARLUS Press Section, headed by Teodorescu-Braniște, had Cocea as one of its first vice presidents, serving alongside Ion Pas.<ref name="ac135"/> Around 1946, Cocea approached Arghezi with a PCR offer to become a paid communist writer. According to his own classified report for the party, he was unable to persuade his former friend to join him in this cause.<ref name="stamoral1"/> Cocea's various efforts still earned praise from official poet [[Mihai Beniuc]], who included his colleague among the writers most active in disseminating communist principles after August 1944.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Cassian Maria Spiridon]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/TATAoct3.html "Un congres al scriitorilor" (I)], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', October 2003</ref> According to Tănase, Cocea "offered himself to the Soviet occupier, with the same [[amoralism]] and cynicism that have been following him through life."<ref name="stamoral1"/>
Between 1944 and 1946,<ref name="bc184"/> Cocea was also editor and publisher of ''Victoria'' ("Victory") daily. Although nominally independent, it has been claimed by journalist Victor Frunză that this paper was a tribune for the PCR, supporting the policies of [[communization]], and popularizing [[Stalinism]].<ref>Frunză, p.214, 245</ref><ref name="ppgmemento">{{ro icon}} Petru Popescu Gogan, [http://revista.memoria.ro/?location=view_article&id=351 "Memento!"], in ''Revista Memoria'', Nr. 28</ref> It fostered a new generation of journalists and activists, among them [[Vera Călin]],<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Geo Șerban]], introductory note to [[Vera Călin]], [http://www.romlit.ro/frnturi_de_via_opiuni_cuvinte "Frânturi de viață, opțiuni, cuvinte"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 31/2005</ref> [[B. Elvin]],<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Geo Șerban]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/De-pe-un-pisc-al-confirmarilor*articleID_18194-articles_details.html "De pe un pisc al confirmărilor"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 386, August 2007</ref> [[George Mărgărit]]<ref>{{ro icon}} Iulian Marcel Ciubotaru, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/CIUBOTARUsep11.htm "Un document de arhivă inedit: autobiografia poetului George Mărgărit"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', September 2011</ref> and [[Marius Mircu]].<ref>{{ro icon}} B. Mehr, [http://www.romanianjewish.org/db/pdf/nr302_303/pagina23.pdf "Marius Mircu ne-a părăsit înainte de a împlini un secol de viață"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 302-303 (1102-1103), September 2008, p.23</ref> Other ''Victoria'' contributors, including Iosifescu, [[Constantin Balmuș]], the avant-garde writers [[Radu Boureanu]] and [[Geo Dumitrescu]], wrote articles which condemned the various traditional seats of learning and the [[Romanian Academy]], as "[[reactionary]]", while naming the senior far right supporters in culture (from [[Ioan Alexandru Brătescu-Voinești]] and [[D. Caracostea]] to [[P. P. Panaitescu]] and [[Ion Petrovici]]).<ref name="ppgmemento"/>
On March 31, 1945, Cocea replaced the disgraced Carandino as Inspector-general of the Romanian theaters, and began introducing [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censorship]].<ref>Catalan, p.187, 188, 190</ref> In September 1947, a few months before the [[Communist Romania|Romanian communist regime]] officially took over, Cocea was reelected to the Writers' Society Leadership Committee.<ref name="vdssr"/> Together with Ion Pas, the [[Ministry of Culture and National Patrimony|Minister of Arts]], he introduced legislation that severely curtailed the Romanian dramatic repertoire. It was largely impractical, causing an uproar in the theatrical community, and leading to Cocea's demotion in December 1947.<ref>Catalan, p.190-191</ref>
On January 9, 1948, Cocea was made Vice President of the reformed Writers' Society (later [[Writers' Union of Romania]]), alongside Galaction, [[Gábor Gaál]] and [[Al. Șahighian]] ([[Zaharia Stancu]] was the President, [[Ion Călugăru]] the General Secretary).<ref name="cv79"/> He died the next year at his home in Sighișoara, shortly after a spiritual crisis had brought him back into the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name="gc919"/>
==Personal life and family== N. D. Cocea had a notoriously promiscuous lifestyle, a favorite topic of gossip and urban legends. In his recollections, fellow journalist [[Constantin Beldie]] alleged that Cocea once owned a summer [[pavilion]] frequented by debauched young women, a veritable "[[seraglio]]".<ref name="ammundus">Adrian Majuru, [http://plural-magazine.com/article_mundus-inversus.html "Mundus Inversus"], in the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.plural-magazine.com/ Plural Magazine]'', Nr. 26/2005</ref> A writer named Bogdan Amaru noted in autumn 1934 that "Nicu D. Cocea always walks around with two girls on his arms. The women sense in him the writer who is at all times willing to render them immortal with the tip of his pen."<ref>{{ro icon}} Bogdan Amaru, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/societateademaine/pdf/BCUCLUJ_FP_279802_1934_011_011.pdf "Jurnal de toamnă"], in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 11/1934, p.162 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> However, the intelligence agents keeping Cocea under surveillance during the 1930s and '40s collected rumors according to which their target was a [[homosexual]].<ref name="stamoral1"/> The ''[[Țara Noastră]]'' polemicists also claimed that Cocea's [[pederasty]] was a matter of public record.<ref name="tninsemnari"/>
Cocea's marriages and relationships resulted in four children: [[Tantzi Cocea|Tantzi]], [[Dina Cocea|Dina]], Radu and [[Ioana-Maria Cocea|Ioana-Maria]] (also known as Maria Cocea).<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> Florica Mille, who was his first wife, left him for his many affairs with younger women, even though, Dina Cocea recalls, she was forever fascinated by his intellect.<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> After the 1920 divorce, Cocea is said to have lived with a Maria<ref name="stamoral1"/> or Zoe Grigorescu.<ref name="gc919"/> Tantzi, who was born to him from this relationship (1909),<ref name="stamoral1"/> was the first wife of Liviu Ciulley (father of the award-winning filmmaker [[Liviu Ciulei]]).<ref>Gheorghe Florescu, ''Confesiunile unui cafegiu'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 2008, p.228. {{ISBN|978-973-50-2208-2}}</ref> The writer's second marriage, to Lila Stănescu, was allegedly one [[Marriage of convenience|of convenience]],<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> and he was at the time still in a physical relationship with Gina Manolescu-Strunga, the reason for his [[statutory rape]] trial. Their affair continued even after Gina married art critic [[Petru Comarnescu]], and she was carrying Cocea's child when that marriage was annulled.<ref name="ssscandaluri"/><ref>{{ro icon}} Lucian Nastasă, [http://history-cluj.ro/Istorie/cercet/Nastasa/IntelectualiiSiPromovarea.pdf ''Intelectualii și promovarea socială (pentru o morfologie a câmpului universitar)''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817224044/http://history-cluj.ro/Istorie/cercet/Nastasa/IntelectualiiSiPromovarea.pdf |date=2011-08-17 }}, Editura Nereamia Napocae, Cluj-Napoca, 2003; [[e-book]] version at the [[Romanian Academy]]'s George Bariț Institute of History, p.117, 138-139</ref><ref name="ascomarnescu">{{ro icon}} Andrei Stavilă, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/STAVILAian5.html "Eveniment: Jurnalul lui Petru Comarnescu"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', January 2005</ref>
The daughter, Ioana-Maria, was later recognized by Cocea, and earned her artistic reputation as a sculptor;<ref name="msraristocratia"/> through her mother, she was related to the [[Ghica family]] and to the banker Iosif Pincas.<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> Like Comarnescu before him, Cocea became disenchanted with Gina and was repelled by her public persona: his diaries contain sarcastic comments on her supposed lack of principles and naïvete, calling her ''Gina Balamuc'' ("Madhouse Gina").<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> After parting with Cocea, Gina was married to communist journalist [[Ghiță Ionescu]] (later known as an [[anti-communist]] academic, relocated to England).<ref name="ssscandaluri"/> In the 1940s, while in Sighișoara, Cocea had as a mistress Ioana Mosora, who was more than 40 years his junior.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="ssscandaluri"/><ref name="gc919"/> One of his final projects was to educate Ioana, the daughter of impoverished peasants,<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="ssscandaluri"/> on art and literary history.<ref name="gc919"/>
According to literary historian [[George Călinescu]], Cocea was only devoted to "the cause of the proletariat" in his public life: "in his most intimate life, an aristocrat, worshiping the established order and the supreme factor."<ref name="gc919"/> The [[Anticlericalism|anticlerical]] journalist was always troubled by the matters of belief and organized religion. In ''Spre Roma'', Cocea confesses about having piously knelt in front of [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s ''[[The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)|Last Supper]]'', and about finding the arguments of [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] preachers to be almost irresistible.<ref name="gc919"/> Cocea was still active in the [[Freemasonry in Romania|Romanian Freemasonry]]: he stood by the dissident Masons who pledged allegiance to [[Masonic Lodge Officers|Grand Masters]] [[George Valentin Bibescu]] and [[Grigore C. Grigoriu]]; from 1945, he was himself a Deputy Grand Master.<ref name="msmessage"/> Reputedly, it was him who advised Grigoriu and [[Mihail Noradunghian]] to send this [[Masonic Lodge]] into "sleep", as a means to preempt [[Suppression of Freemasonry|communist suppression]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/masonii-din-romania-pro-sau-contra-intereselor-nationale-603879.html "Masonii din România - PRO sau CONTRA intereselor naționale"], in ''[[Evenimentul Zilei]]'', February 13, 1998</ref> In old age, he rediscovered Romanian Orthodoxy. He made arrangements for his parents to be reburied in Sighișoara, recognized all his illegitimate children, and, on his death bed, demanded to be buried with an [[Christian burial|Orthodox service]] performed by his old friend Galaction.<ref name="gc919"/>
Cocea's image with his two friends Galaction and Arghezi had a more shady side. Cocea himself divulged Arghezi's private anti-communism in his 1946 report to the PCR overseers, recording that Arghezi rejected offers for collaboration with sarcasm and pride.<ref name="stamoral1"/> Arghezi's own private notes, and some of his published lampoons, contain some biting remarks about Cocea's communist career.<ref>{{ro icon}} Radu Bogdan, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Alte-capricii-de-poet*articleID_3024-articles_details.html "Alte capricii de poet"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 121, June 2002</ref><ref name="stegalact">{{ro icon}} [[Stelian Tănase]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Pe-tatal-meu-denuntul-nu-l-a-afectat-cu-nimic-era-intotdeauna-bine-dispus.-Dialog-cu-Elena-Galaction*articleID_12785-articles_details.html " 'Pe tatăl meu denunțul nu l-a afectat cu nimic, era întotdeauna bine dispus'. Dialog cu Elena Galaction"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 260, March 2005</ref> In a 2005 interview, Galaction's daughter Elena also stated that her father had only remained in contact with Cocea because of Cocea's kinship with Zoe Marcou-Galaction; the family, she claimed, mistrusted and feared Cocea, whom Zoe herself likened to the devil, but whose conversation skills they all found irresistibly entertaining.<ref name="stegalact"/>
==Literary work==
===Satirist=== In George Călinescu's definition, Cocea was "more of a [[Yellow journalism|yellow journalist]] than a talented one".<ref name="gc919"/> Reviewing ''Fecior de slugă'' for ''[[Gând Românesc]]'' magazine in October 1933, cultural journalist C. Pastia sarcastically commented that Cocea's lampoons had "taught boys how to curse", in which action he identified the Cocea's lifelong objective.<ref name="pastia289"/> Similar assessments were later passed by other authors and researchers. [[Paul Cernat]] described Cocea the pamphleteer as "feared" and "vitriolic",<ref name="pc29"/> while [[Stelian Tănase]] summarized his writing as "sharp, polemical and vulgar".<ref name="stamoral1"/> Likewise, critic [[Mihai Zamfir]] calls Cocea's [[Republicanism|republican]] pamphlets "filthy", accusing them of promoting, together with the "stupid little poems" of the much older [[Alexandru Vlahuță]], a distorted image of the Romanian monarchy.<ref name="mzstapini">{{ro icon}} [[Mihai Zamfir]], [http://www.romlit.ro/stpni_i_supui "Stăpîni și supuși"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 5/2006</ref> Stelian Tănase also notes that Cocea resorted in [[blackmail]], just like his ex-pupil turned rival [[Pamfil Șeicaru]], but that he was less interested than Șeicaru in accumulating fortunes.<ref name="stamoral1"/> Cocea himself was vexed by Șeicaru's style. In his definition, it was the literary equivalent of "[[postilion]] curses".<ref name="nmmoralitati"/>
The harsh pronouncements on Cocea's journalistic contributions are nuanced or contradicted by other writers and critics. [[Scarlat Callimachi]] spoke of his comrade, the "feared polemicist", as in reality "a good man" of "amazing generosity", and, stylistically, "a poet": "Even in his most violent articles one finds glimpses of true poetry."<ref name="sc46-47"/> The latter trait, Callimachi assessed, survived no matter how hard Cocea trained himself to repress it.<ref name="sc46">Callimachi, p.46</ref> Cocea's skill was emphasized by his foe, Comarnescu, who believed Cocea to be a "semi-failure" as an intellectual, but also a "joker" of genius.<ref name="ascomarnescu"/> According to Pastia: "no one in [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]] has ever speculated [[paradox]] with as much courage and talent."<ref name="pastia289"/> Writing in 1936, the young ''[[Facla]]'' essayist [[Eugène Ionesco]] (later a world-famous playwright), listed Cocea and Arghezi among the "peaks" of an older generation, as Romania's two "greatest lampoonists".<ref>[[Eugène Ionesco]], [http://www.plural-magazine.com/article_on-the-generation-in-shambles-1936.html "On the Generation in Shambles, 1936"], in the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.plural-magazine.com/ Plural Magazine]'', Nr. 29/2007</ref> Various other authors have also seen in Cocea a founding figure of the more satirical and politically aware side of modern [[Romanian humor]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Radu Cosașu]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/la-centru-si-la-margine/articol/blestemul-telegramelor-havas "Blestemul telegramelor Havas"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 194, October 2007; Mihaela Mureșan, [http://www.studia.ubbcluj.ro/download/pdf/355.pdf "Pamfletul ca text jurnalistic inedit"], in the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]]'s ''Ephemerides'', Nr. 1/2008, p.112, 115; Ion Vasile Șerban, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Pamfletul-intre-fond-si-forma*articleID_3739-articles_details.html "Pamfletul între fond și formă"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 50, February 2001; Val Talpalaru, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/PRESAiul10.html "ComPresa Revistelor"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', July 2010</ref>
===''Poet-Poetă''=== Cocea's youthful debut with ''Poet-Poetă'' was his homage to [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolist]] [[prose poetry]], colored with a strongly erotic tinge. According to George Călinescu, the book, "vehemently [[Priapism|priapic]] and monotonous in its excess", borrows its tone from [[Alexandru Macedonski]], its titillating subject from [[Pierre Louÿs]], and its plot from [[Mihai Eminescu]] (the novel ''Cezara'').<ref name="gc919"/> The protagonists of ''Poet-Poetă'', Iulius and Ersilia, living on love and desire, discover each other's bodies and then the joy of dying of one's own volition, hurling themselves off a precipice.<ref name="gc919"/> Writing in 1911, [[Ilarie Chendi]] noted that the book was Cocea's first known blunder, speculating that literary failure had relegated Cocea to the promotion of other, more talented, Symbolists.<ref name="icvieata"/>
Călinescu sees the positive aspect of ''Poet-Poetă'' in its "delicate description" of the human form (Ersilia's hair, for instance, is ''stofă fără preț'', "priceless fabric").<ref name="gc919"/> Fellow literary historian and critic [[Ștefan Cazimir]] has included Cocea's work among the Symbolist novels directly influenced by [[Vienna Secession]] art and the Secessionists' feminization of nature.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ștefan Cazimir]], [http://www.romlit.ro/secesionismul_n_literatura_romn_vi "Secesionismul în literatura română" (VI)], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 13-14/1999</ref> Such traits also stand out in Galaction's biblical preface, a new ''[[Song of Songs]]'': "Ersilia's eyes are as green as the depths of the ponds at [[Heshbon]]; and her breasts like twin does grazing among the lilies."<ref name="gc919"/> These interventions were held against Galaction by literary historian [[Eugen Lovinescu]] (an outspoken adversary of the ''Viața Socială'' writers): "A militant Orthodox, [Galaction] prefaced in his youth novels which defile all things sacred".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/istoria_unei_antipatii__e._lovinescu_i_gala_galaction "Istoria unei antipatii – E. Lovinescu și Gala Galaction"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 47/2004</ref>
In 1908, when he castigated both Symbolism and "perverted eroticism", Cocea left a detailed list of authors he considered "degenerate" and "bourgeois": [[Gabriele d'Annunzio]], [[Alexandre Dumas, fils|Dumas-fils]], [[Maurice Maeterlinck]], [[Anna de Noailles]], [[Georges Ohnet]], [[Marcel Prévost]], and [[Oscar Wilde]].<ref>Mitchievici, p.101</ref> According to literary historian [[Angelo Mitchievici]], the substance of such "class-based criticism" was equivalent to the [[biological determinism]] of Cocea's nationalist adversaries, announcing the absolutes of fascism ("[[degenerate art]]") and communism (the [[Zhdanov Doctrine]]).<ref>Mitchievici, p.102</ref>
===''Vinul de viață lungă''=== ''Vinul de viață lungă'' is considered by some to be Cocea's main work as a novelist.<ref name="bc179">Camboulives, p.179</ref> The main character, Manole Arcaș, is, like Cocea himself, a Moldavian boyar. Successive episodes in the book reveal his complex worldview: Arcaș is an [[Atheism|atheist]] with modernist sensibilities, a lover of nature, and a [[utopian socialist]] who has been turning his estate into a [[commune]].<ref>Camboulives, p.179-182</ref> Having reached a venerable age, he slowly reveals the secret of his longevity in conversations with the much younger judge: after decades of experimentation, the Arcaș estate produces a special sort of [[Moldavian wine]]; the grapes were [[Pressed (wine)|pressed]] by Manole and a [[Roma minority in Romania|Romani (Gypsy)]] girl, in the course of their love-making.<ref>Călinescu, p.919; Camboulives, p.182</ref> The object of Arcaș' [[Sexual fetishism|olfactory fetish]], the girl has died a tragic death, inspiring Manole to take up the winery project as a sort of symbolic rebirth.<ref>Călinescu, p.919; Camboulives, p.182-183</ref>
With its aesthetics and its tone, ''Vinul de viață lungă'' is an unusual sample of militant literature, contrasting with the work of socialist or [[Poporanism|Poporanist]] writers from Cocea's lifetime. French historian Bernard Camboulives notes that Cocea made a point of reacting against Poporanists' call to preserve "Romanian specificity".<ref name="bc179"/> Similarly, George Călinescu notes that the Poporanist setting is given an original twist in Cocea's novel, with the erotic interludes.<ref name="gc919"/> As Callimachi writes, the book is a rare moment in which Cocea the poet vanquished Cocea the journalist,<ref name="sc46"/> while Camboulives sees in it "a eulogy to life, to love, to the senses and to the most elevated thoughts".<ref>Camboulives, p.183</ref> In Călinescu's more skeptical interpretation, it merely stands for "a journalistic narrative, with the stylistic decency of well-read men", its author being less than a "creator", its dialogues just "chatter".<ref name="gc919"/>
===''Fecior de slugă'', ''Pentr-un petec...'', ''Nea Nae''=== During the [[interwar period]], Cocea could at times register significant success, but it was largely owed to the scandalous nature of his novels. The issue was taken into consideration by Călinescu, who referred to Cocea's "exaggerated, but explainable" popularity.<ref name="gc919"/> C. Pastia also suspected Cocea of pulling a prank, "leaving the impression that he had dedicated himself to literature" in ''Vinul de viață lungă'', and then returning to the political stage with novel-lampoons.<ref name="pastia289"/> Cocea also found critics among his fellow modernists: writing in 1935, modernist critic [[Lucian Boz]] created a separation between the "[[Pornography|pornographic]] novels" of Cocea or [[D. V. Barnoschi]], which "have [[orgasm]] as their goal", and the controversial but "brave" literature of [[James Joyce]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Lucian Boz]], [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/societateademaine/pdf/BCUCLUJ_FP_279802_1935_012_005.pdf "Discuții și recenzii. Octav Șuluțiu: ''Ambigen''"], in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 5/1935, p.101 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
''Fecior de slugă'', the first of Cocea's [[political novel]]s, takes its artistic inspiration from the ''[[fin de siècle]]'' novelist [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]], creator of the social climbing prototype [[Dinu Păturică]].<ref>Călinescu, p.919; Pastia, p.289</ref> Cocea's Dinu is Tănase Bojogeanu, the "son of the servant" referred to in the book's title. As a child, he is shown competing in school with Nelu Azan, the daydreaming aristocrat, profiting from Azan's generosity and overtaking him in many respects.<ref>Călinescu, p.919; Pastia, p.289-290</ref> However, while Nelu preserves ideals which lead him into the communist movement, Tănase, the corrupt clerk, rises through the ranks to become King's Commissioner.<ref name="gc919"/> The two are pitted against each other, their ideological conflict made worse when Bojogeanu sells a young female communist into [[sexual slavery]].<ref name="gc919"/>
Present throughout the work are masked portrayals of Cocea's political allies and adversaries. Pastia, who described such cameos as both cartoonish and interesting, identified [[Alexandru Averescu]], [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]], [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]], [[I. C. Frimu]], [[Dumitru Iliescu-Turtucaia]], [[Take Ionescu]], [[Nicolae Iorga]] and some others.<ref>Pastia, p.289, 290</ref> Pastia also suggests that the central theme (Bojogeanu as the [[bourgeois]] suffocating ancient boyardom) is conventional and ultimately irrelevant: "That may well be, and we agree that our morals may tolerate the decay of the Azans and the ascent of the Bojogeanus. But this did not a novel make. An issue of ''Facla'' would have sufficed."<ref name="pastia290">Pastia, p.290</ref> Călinescu spoke with displeasure about ''Fecior de slugă'' as an illustration of Cocea's "strident, violent style, excessively vulgar and of a sexuality that is never redeemed by a hint of whatever is eternally human."<ref name="gc919"/> Pastia however found that Cocea wrote his book with noticeable talent "in rendering that which is vulgar", a Romanian answer to [[Charles Baudelaire]]'s ''[[Les Fleurs du mal]]''.<ref name="pastia290"/>
''Pentr-un petec de negreață'', with its name borrowed from peri-urban [[Romanian folklore]],<ref name="ammundus"/> shows its male protagonist Andrei Vaia alternating between dreams of [[free love]] in the countryside and the adulation of Bucharest as a hotspot of erotic pursuits. Of the adventures depicted, some are believed to have been modeled on Cocea's own sexual exploits.<ref name="stamoral1"/><ref name="ammundus"/> A pivotal moment in the novel shows Andrei discovering that his Bucharest lover, Mira, is cheating on him with the hunchback Bergher, who has purchased her attentions with stockings and silk.<ref name="ammundus"/> Through Vaia's monologues, the book gives Cocea's views about the female psyche and bodily needs, the supposedly eternal insecurity of men, and the mystery of female orgasm.<ref name="ammundus"/> ''Pentr-un petec...'' doubled as a barely disguised satire of the interwar political class, in this case specifically directed at the [[National Peasants' Party]]—according to Călinescu, this was Cocea's selling tactic, as were its advertised depictions of "fornication" and "sexual abnormalities", or its licentious quotation from the [[Book of Proverbs]].<ref name="gc919"/>
In ''Nea Nae'', the eponymous protagonist is a boorish and thick potentate, always on the hunt for "beastly erotic pleasures" (Călinescu), sometimes accompanied by thinly disguised political figures of the interwar.<ref name="gc919"/> Călinescu was especially critical of Nae's speech patterns, caricatured "without the gifts of the [[picturesque]]".<ref name="gc919"/>
==Legacy== Cocea greatly influenced the journalistic style of young Ion Vinea<ref name="isserviciul"/><ref name="pcrisipitor"/><ref>Cernat, ''Avangarda'', p.63, 98, 107, 130, 132, 133-134, 140, 220</ref> and Scarlat Callimachi.<ref name="sc46-47"/> In addition to his presence in the memoirs or diaries of his friends and enemies, Cocea is the republican revolutionist in ''Cronică de familie'' ("Family Chronicle"), by the communist writer [[Petru Dumitriu]]—a text allegedly plagiarized from Vinea's unpublished works.<ref name="ivdumitriu"/> Among the better-known visual portrayals of Cocea is a 1928 ink drawing by [[Marcel Janco]].<ref>[https://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/05812/0B465782A754869FF277BE56050C2B79CED2B15B.html ''Portretul scriitorului N.D. Cocea''], [[Europeana]] entry; retrieved February 21, 2011</ref>
Some of N. D. Cocea's writings enjoyed a good standing throughout [[Communist Romania|Romania's communist period]]. During the early 1960s, official textbooks described him as one of those who covered the gap between 19th-century [[Literary realism|Realism]] and [[Socialist realism in Romania|Romanian Socialist Realism]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/canonul_literar_proletcultist_ii "Canonul literar proletcultist" (II)], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 28/2008</ref> In particular, the communist regime overplayed Cocea's criticism of the Romanian monarchy, glorifying him as someone who had undermined the credibility of [[Michael I of Romania|Michael I]] and his predecessors.<ref name="gpproces"/><ref name="mzstapini"/> In one instance, communist historiography even claimed that Cocea and Arghezi had served time for their 1912 anti-monarchy campaign, taking ''Facla'' lampoons at face value.<ref name="gpproces"/> Cocea's World War II diaries were passed on to his relatives in Switzerland, and have not been published except for the short fragments hosted in the 1960s by two Romanian reviews: ''[[Magazin Istoric]]''<ref name="stamoral1"/> and ''[[Secolul XX]]''.<ref name="mseisenstein"/> In 1970, an edition of his ''Jurnal'' ("Diary") was issued by the PCR's [[Editura Politică]].<ref name="giflupu"/> A previously unknown novel by Cocea was signaled in the late 1970s, and noted for its virulent attacks on [[Pamfil Șeicaru]].<ref name="nmmoralitati"/>
Cocea's literature and political controversy were also publicized outside Romania. From his refuge in [[Francoist Spain]], Șeicaru made public his decades-long polemic with Cocea. His repeated talk about Cocea's immorality prompted literary historian [[Nicolae Manolescu]] to note a paradox: "It is somewhat strange to see accusations of immorality being launched by people who, beyond their talent [...], do not even possess the most basic moral sense. The mere fact that the pamphlets they hurl at each other, like hogwash, have morality as their stake (never their own, always the other's), should make one think."<ref name="nmmoralitati"/> A [[French-language]] translation of ''Vinul de viață lungă'' was published by Jean de Palacio (''Le Vin de longue vie'', Le Serpent à Plumes, 2000).<ref>Camboulives, p.183, 374</ref> According to Romanian literary critic [[Mircea Iorgulescu]], the positive reception of such works in France "would probably astound the Romanian literary environment, for whom Cocea hardly even exists."<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Mircea Iorgulescu]], [http://www.cuvantul.ro/articol/?artID=5&nr=338 "Literatura română văzută de la Paris"], in ''[[Cuvântul (literary magazine)|Cuvântul]]'', Nr. 338, August 2005</ref>
Streets named after Cocea exist in Bucharest, Sighișoara, [[Brașov]], [[Oradea]], [[Sibiu]] and [[Timișoara]]. His residence in Sighișoara is preserved by the local authorities as a "memorial house".<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://adrcentru.ro/Document_Files/turismul%20cultural_2ttj6s.pdf ''Regiunea 7 Centru: Turismul cultural''], [[Centru (development region)|Centru]] Agency for Regional Development, p.9; retrieved February 21, 2011</ref> The same city is home to the N. D. Cocea Literary Club, established 1979.<ref>{{ro icon}} Vasile V. Luca, [http://www.cuvantul-liber.ro/articol.asp?ID=46421 "Cenaclul N.D Cocea-Anotimpuri, la ceas aniversar. Lansare de carte"], in ''[[Cuvântul Liber (Târgu Mureș)|Cuvântul Liber]]'', November 27, 2009</ref>

'''Noisy investigations''' are used by the [[Church of Scientology]] to intimidate, harass, and attack their enemies. The Church used to openly label such people as [[Fair Game (Scientology)|Fair Game]]. The goal of a noisy investigation may not be to find out anything, but to harass the person being investigated. The procedure is to contact friends, neighbours, co-workers, etc. and inform them that they are investigating crimes by the target person.<ref>Atack, Jon [http://www.clambake.org/archive/books/apobs/bs4-5.htm A Piece of Blue Sky, Chapter 5: Hubbard's Travels] © Jon Atack 1990. (convenience link provided by Xenu.net)</ref>
A 1966 Hubbard Communications Office Executive Letter entitled "How to do a NOISY Investigation" described the practice as follows: "You find out where he or she works or worked, ''doctor'', dentist, friends, neighbours, ''anyone'', and 'phone 'em up and say, 'I am investigating Mr/Mrs .......... for criminal activities as he/she has been trying to prevent Man's freedom and is restricting my religious freedom and that of my friends and children, etc'".<ref>HCO Executive Letter, 5 September 1966; reprinted in [[Foster Report|The Foster Report]], p. 144</ref><ref name="PCSoS-C9">Cooper, Paulette [http://www.clambake.org/archive/books/tsos/sos-09.html#c11 ''The Scandal of Scientology'' Chapter 9: ''Attacking the Attackers''] Copyright © 1971 (convenience link by Xenu.net)</ref> The investigation may also be done by hired detectives.
A memo, reprinted in the British paper "People", said: "We want at least one bad mark on every psychiatrist in England, a murder, an assault, or a rape or more than one.... This is Project Psychiatry. We will remove them."<ref name="PCSoS-C9" />
Some [[Scientology|Scientologists]] claim that their policy of "[[Fair Game (Scientology)|Fair Game]]" is no longer in effect, but critics of the Church maintain that whether the rule is still written in Scientology policy or not, the policy is still adhered to today. Some ex-Scientologists have claimed that the cancellation of the policy only cancelled the use of the words "fair game" and did not change the actual policy.
==See also== {{Portal|Scientology}} * [[Scientology controversy#"Dead agenting"|Dead Agenting]] * [[Suppressive Person]] * [[Fair Game (Scientology)]] * [[R2-45]] * [[Game (Scientology)]]

'''Progressive Baptists''' are members of the [[Progressive National Baptist Convention]] or any number of Baptist groups that are ''progressive'' in their methods. Groups such as the [[Alliance of Baptists]], [[Cooperative Baptist Fellowship]], and many others frequently use ''progressive'' as a self-descriptive term. They emphasize their interest in moderate to liberal theology, as well as new ideas, methods, and opportunities.
==See also== * [[Alliance of Baptists]] * [[Association of Welcoming and Affirming Baptists]] * [[Baptist Peace Fellowship of North America]] * [[Cooperative Baptist Fellowship]] * [[American Baptist Churches USA]] * [[Progressive National Baptist Convention]]
