{{Italicize title}} {{Infobox beverage | name = Pulque | image = Pulquebottle.JPG | caption = Bottle of unflavored pulque with bamboo cap | type = Alcoholic beverage | origin = [[Mesoamerica]] | color = milky-white }}
'''Pulque''' {{Audio-IPA|Pulque1.ogg|['pulke]|}} (occasionally referred to as '''agave wine'''{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}) is an [[alcoholic beverage]] made from the [[fermentation (food)|fermented]] sap of the [[Agave americana|maguey (agave)]] plant. It is traditional to central [[Mexico]], where it has been produced for millennia.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fV6nSXZ0KS8C&lpg=PA48&dq=pulque%20thousands%20of%20years&pg=PA48#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Coping with Alcohol and Drug Problems: The Experiences of Family Members in Three Contrasting Cultures | year=2005 | pages=48 | quote=One of the most traditional drinks is pulque, fermented from the maguey cactus, and produced in the region for thousands of years.| isbn=9781134702732 | author1=Orford | first1=Jim | last2=Natera | first2=Guillermina | last3=Copello | first3=Alex | last4=Atkinson | first4=Carol | last5=Mora | first5=Jazmin | last6=Velleman | first6=Richard | last7=Crundall | first7=Ian | last8=Tiburcio | first8=Marcela | last9=Templeton | first9=Lorna | last10=Walley | first10=Gwen }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jjTaAAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA106&dq=pulque%20thousands%20of%20years&pg=PA106#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Local Foods Meet Global Foodways: Tasting History | year=2012 | pages=106 | isbn=978-0415829953 | quote=Central in precolonial ceremonial and food cultures, pulque (''octli'' in Nahuatl) has been produced for thousands of years.| author1=Lawrance | first1=Benjamin N | last2=Peña | first2=Carolyn de la }}</ref> It has the color of milk, somewhat [[Viscosity|viscous]] consistency and a sour yeast-like taste.<ref name="sacred"/>
The drink's history extends far back into the [[Mesoamerica]]n period, when it was considered sacred, and its use was limited to certain classes of people.<ref name="whatis">{{cite web |author= Del Maguey, Single Village Mezcal |title= What is Pulque? |url= http://www.mezcal.com/pulque.html |accessdate= 11 September 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090604215855/http://www.mezcal.com/pulque.html |archivedate= 4 June 2009 |df= }}</ref> After the [[Spanish Conquest of Mexico]], the drink became secular and its consumption rose.<ref name="lugares">{{cite web |first=Anne |last=Bonnefoy |title= Haciendas pulqueras de Apan y Zempoala |url=http://www.lugaresdemexico.com/apan-zempoala.html |trans-title=Pulque haciendas in Apan and Zempoala |language=Spanish |date=October 2007 |quote= |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref> The consumption of pulque reached its peak in the late 19th century.<ref name="madness">{{cite web |title= The story of pulque (or Mayan Madness!)|url= http://www.tequilamescal.com/pulque.htm |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref> In the 20th century, the drink fell into decline, mostly because of competition from [[beer]], which became more prevalent with the arrival of European immigrants. There are some efforts to revive the drink's popularity through tourism.<ref name="lugares"/>
==Description== Pulque is a milk-colored, somewhat [[Viscosity|viscous]] liquid that produces a light foam. It is made by fermenting the [[sap]] of certain types of maguey (agave) plants. In contrast, [[mezcal]] is made from the cooked heart of certain agave plants, and [[tequila]], a variety of mezcal, is made all or mostly from the [[blue agave]]. About six varieties of maguey are best used for the production of pulque.<ref name="sacred">{{cite news |title= Aztecs' Sacred Drink Pulque Losing Out to Beer in Mexico |url= http://www.medindia.net/news/Aztecs-Sacred-Drink-Pulque-Losing-Out-to-Beer-in-Mexico-29730-1.htm |agency=Medindia |date=2007-11-23 |accessdate=12 September 2009 }}</ref><ref name="whatis"/> The name ''pulque'' is derived from [[Nahuatl]]. The original name of the drink was ''iztāc octli'' {{IPA-nah|ˈistaːk ˈokt͡ɬi|}} (white pulque), the term pulque was probably mistakenly derived by the Spanish from the ''octli poliuhqui'' {{IPA-nah|ˈokt͡ɬi poˈliwki|}}, which meant "spoiled pulque".<ref name="restaurantes">{{cite web |title=El pulque, bebida de los dioses |url=http://www.restaurantesdemexico.com.mx/249/Vinos_y_Bebidas_El_Pulque__Bebida_De_Los_Dioses.html |publisher=Restaurantes de Mexico |trans-title=Pulque: The Drink of the Gods |language=Spanish |doi= |date=2009-09-13 |accessdate=13 September 2009}}</ref>
==Maguey== [[File:Maguey.jpg|thumb|Close up of a maguey plant]] The maguey plant, also called a "century plant" in English, is native to Mexico. It grows best in the cold, dry climates of the rocky central highlands to the north and east of [[Mexico City]], especially in the states of [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]] and [[Tlaxcala]]. Maguey has been cultivated at least since 200 CE in [[Tula, Hidalgo|Tula]], [[Tulancingo]] and [[Teotihuacan]], and wild plants have been exploited for far longer. The plant historically has had a number of uses. Fibers can be extracted from the thick leaves to make rope or fabric, its thorns can be used as needles or punches and the membrane covering the leaves can be used as paper or for cooking.<ref name="lugares"/><ref name="mexdes">{{cite web |first=Beatriz |last=Oliver Vega |title=El uso de maguey |url=http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/notas/6844-El-uso-del-maguey |publisher=Mexico Desconocido |location=Mexico City |trans-title=Use of Maguey |language=Spanish |date=April–May 1995 |accessdate=13 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417030644/http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/notas/6844-El-uso-del-maguey |archivedate=17 April 2009 |df= }}</ref> The name ''maguey'' was given by the Spanish, who picked it up from the [[Taíno people|Taíno]]. This is still its common name in Spanish, with ''Agave'' being its scientific generic or technical name. The [[Nahuatl]] name of the plant is ''metl''.<ref name="soumaya">{{cite web |first=Mónica López |last=Velarde Estrada |title=El Descubrimiento del Pulque |url=http://www.soumaya.com.mx/navegar/anteriores/anteriores05/febrero/edp.html |publisher=Soumaya Museum |location=Mexico City |trans-title=The Discovery of Pulque |language=Spanish |accessdate=3 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140218233426/http://www.soumaya.com.mx/navegar/anteriores/anteriores05/febrero/edp.html |archivedate=18 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
The manufacturing process of pulque is complex and required the death of the maguey plant.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gately|first1=Iain|title=Drink: A Cultural History of Alcohol|date=May 2009|publisher=Gotham Books|location=New York|isbn=978-1-592-40464-3|page=97}}</ref> As the plant nears maturity, the center begins to swell and elongate as the plant gathers stored sugar to send up a single flower stalk, which may reach up to 20 feet in height. However, plants destined for pulque production have this flower stalk cut off, leaving a depressed surface 12-18 inches in diameter. In this center, the maguey sap, known as ''[[aguamiel]]'' (honeywater), collects.<ref name="barrios">{{cite book |last1=De Barrios |first1=Virginia B. |title=A Guide to Tequila, Mezcal and Pulque |year=2002 |publisher=Minutiae Mexicana S.A de C.V. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968-7074-46-9 |pages=28–31 }}</ref> It takes a maguey plant 12 years to mature enough to produce the sap for pulque.<ref name="Tlaxcala">{{cite web |agency=Notimex |title= Tlaxcala organiza recorridos por haciendas pulqueras |website=El Universal.mx |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/624389.html |trans-title=Tlaxcala organized tours of pulque haciendas |language=Spanish |date=4 September 2009 |accessdate=3 April 2014}}</ref>
==History==
===Mythological origins=== [[File:Mayahuel 1.jpg|thumb|Depiction of the goddess Mayahuel]]
Pulque has been drunk for at least 1,000 years, and its origins are the subject of various stories and myths. Most involve [[Mayahuel]], the goddess of the maguey. It was thought that the aguamiel collecting in the center of the plant was her blood. Other deities, such as the [[Centzon Totochtin]] (400 rabbits) are associated with it, by representing the drink's effects, and are the children of Mayahuel.<ref name="whatis"/><ref name="lugares"/> Another version involving ''Mayahuel'' has her as a mortal woman who discovered how to collect aguamiel but someone named ''Pantecatl'' {{IPA-nah|panˈtekat͡ɬ|}} discovered how to make pulque.<ref name="soumaya"/>
According to another story, pulque was discovered by the ''Tlacuache'' {{IPA-nah|t͡ɬaˈkʷat͡ʃe|}} ([[opossum]]), who used his human-like hands to dig into the maguey and extract the naturally fermenting juice. He became the first drunk. ''Tlacuache'' was thought to set the course of rivers. The rivers he set were generally straight except when he was drunk. Then they follow ''Tlacuache's'' meandering path from cantina to cantina.{{cn|date=December 2016}}
Another account traces the discovery of aguamiel to the [[Toltec Empire]], when a noble named Papantzin was trying to get the emperor to marry his daughter [[Xochitl (Toltec)|Xochitl]]. He sent her to the capital with an offering of ''aguamiel'', honey of the agave plant. The emperor and princess wed, and their son was named ''Meconetzin'' {{IPA-nah|mekoˈnet͡sin|}} (maguey son).<ref name="Xochitl">{{cite news |first=Edmundo |last=Domínguez Aragonés |title=Xiuhtlaltzin, primera reina tolteca y Xóchitl, reina tolteca descubridora del pulque |trans-title=Xiuhtlaltzin, the first Toltec queen and Xochitl, the Toltec queen who discovered pulque |url=http://www.oem.com.mx/elsoldemexico/notas/n564920.htm |newspaper=El Sol de Mexico |location=Mexico City |date= 2008-01-20 |accessdate=13 September 2009 |language=Spanish }}</ref> In other versions of the story, Xochitl is credited with discovering pulque.<ref name="lugares"/>
===Pre-Hispanic period=== [[File:Codex_Mendoza_folio_61r.jpg|thumb|left|[[Codex Mendoza]], an early 16th-century manuscript, showing Aztec elders and pulque in a vessel (lower center)]] [[File:El descubrimiento del pulque, por José María Obregón.jpg|thumb|right|225px|''The discovery of pulque'' by nineteenth-century Mexican painter José Obregón.]] The maguey was one of the most sacred and important plants in ancient Mexico. It had a privileged place in mythology, religious rituals and the Mesoamerican economy. Pulque appears in a number of graphic representations from pre-colonial times, beginning with stone carvings from about 200 CE. The first major work involving pulque is a large mural called the "Pulque Drinkers", unearthed in 1968 at the [[Great Pyramid of Cholula|pyramid of Cholula]], [[Puebla]]. The most likely means of the discovery of aguamiel and fermented pulque was from the observation of rodents who gnaw and scratch at the plant to drink the seeping sap. Fermentation of the aguamiel can take place within the plant itself.<ref name="barrios1013">{{cite book |last1=De Barrios |first1=Virginia B. |title=A Guide to Tequila, Mezcal and Pulque |year=2002 |publisher=Minutiae Mexicana S.A de C.V. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968-7074-46-9 |pages=10–13 }}</ref>
For the indigenous peoples of the central highlands of Mexico, the imbibing of pulque was done only by certain people, under certain conditions. It was a ritual drink, consumed during certain festivals, such as that of the goddess Mayahuel, and the god [[Mixcoatl]]. It was drunk by priests and sacrificial victims, to increase the priests' enthusiasm and to ease the suffering of the victim.<ref name="whatis"/> There are many references in [[Aztec]] codices, such as the Borbonicus Codex, of pulque's use by nobility and priesthood to celebrate victories. Among commoners, it was permitted only to the elderly and pregnant women.<ref name="barrios18">{{cite book |last1=De Barrios |first1=Virginia B. |title=A Guide to Tequila, Mezcal and Pulque |year=2002 |publisher=Minutiae Mexicana S.A de C.V. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968-7074-46-9 |page=18 }}</ref> Production of pulque was ritualized and the brewers were superstitious. They would abstain from sex during the fermentation period because they believed that sexual intercourse would sour the process.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gately|first1=Iain|title=Drink: A Cultural History of Alcohol|date=May 2009|publisher=Gotham Books|location=New York|isbn=978-1-592-40464-3|page=97}}</ref>
===Colonial period===
After the Conquest, pulque lost its sacred character, and both indigenous and Spanish people began to drink it.<ref name="lugares"/> The Spanish initially made no laws regarding its use. It became a lucrative source of tax revenue, but by 1672, public drunkenness had become enough of a problem that the viceregal government created regulations to curtail its consumption. A maximum of 36 "[[pulqueria]]s" were permitted for Mexico City, which had to be located in open areas, be without doors and close at sundown. Food, music, dancing and the co-mingling of the sexes was prohibited. However, pulque continued to play a major role in the socioeconomic history of Mexico during colonial times and in the early years of [[Mexican War of Independence|Independence]]. Through this period, it was the fourth largest source of tax revenue.<ref name="barrios2022">{{cite book |last1=De Barrios |first1=Virginia B. |title=A Guide to Tequila, Mezcal and Pulque |year=2002 |publisher=Minutiae Mexicana S.A de C.V. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968-7074-46-9 |pages=20–22 }}</ref> At the end of the 17th century, the [[Jesuits]] began large-scale production of the drink to finance its educational institutions. In this way, the making of pulque passed from being a home-made brew to one commercially produced.<ref name="lugares"/>
=== Drunkenness in casta painting ===
The [[casta]] system of racial hierarchy was created in Spanish America for elites to classify individuals into groups based on phenotype and perceived social class, and give them characteristics that were supposedly inherent to their group. Often artists portrayed mixed-race castas. This form of [[Mexican art]] portrayed castas in settings that were typical of their social group. The portrayal of pulque was used to show polarization between different castas. Before the [[Spanish colonization of the Americas]], pulque was used for religious ceremonies in [[Mesoamerica]].<ref>William B. Taylor. ''Drinking, Homicide, and Rebellion in Colonial Mexican Villages''. Stanford: Stanford University Press.</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Katzew|first=Ilona|title=Casta Painting|year=2004|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|page=112}}</ref> After the arrival of the Spanish, consumption was widespread among Indigenous Americans and mixed-race castas. This led to many social problems including sexual crimes and violence within the population.
In casta painting, pulque depicted situations the Europeans saw as characteristic of the castas they portrayed. Some of these paintings incorporated images of indigenous Americans and Africans as drunk with bottles appearing in the scenes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bristol|first=Joan|title=You Are What You Drink? Tequila, Maguey and Mexican Identity|url=http://www.globality-gmu.net/archives/2380|publisher=George Mason University|accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref> This is a reason that "shortly after the conquests, colonial officials declared pulque abuse and Indian drunkenness a major concern and committed themselves to addressing its impacts on society".{{attribution needed|date=September 2018}}<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kasiak|first=Neil Robert|title=Fermenting Identities: Race and Pulque Politics in Mexico City between 1519 and 1754|journal=Online Theses and Dissertations|year=2012|issue=Paper 68}}</ref> As a result, some casta painters depicted different castas safely consuming and selling pulque.<ref>{{cite book|last=Katzew|first=Ilona|title=Casta Painting|year=2004|publisher=Yale University|location=New Haven|page=115}}</ref> Other casta painters depicted Indigenous Americans intoxicated in the streets, and incapacitated which as a result required their families to escort them home.<ref>{{cite book|last=Katzew|first=Ilona|title=Casta Painting|year=2004|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|page=120}}</ref> Casta painting was used as a method of social commentary on the destructive use of pulque in everyday society. As the Spanish attempted to crack down on pulque, some casta painters depicted indigenous Americans in safe environments where even children were able to consume pulque. The paintings were meant to show that Spanish regulation was effective in controlling the consumption and distribution of pulque in the colonial period.
===Post colonial period=== [[File:Pulqueria en tacubaya.jpg|thumb|left|A [[pulqueria]] in [[Tacubaya]] in the 1880s]] Production of pulque exploded after Independence, when the regulation of pulque producers ended, and Mexican nationalism increased.<ref name="soumaya"/> From then until the 1860s, pulque [[hacienda]]s multiplied, especially in Hidalgo and Tlaxcala states. In 1866, the first railway between [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]] and Mexico City began operations, crossing through Hidalgo. This line was soon known as the "Pulque Train" because it brought supplies of the drink daily to the capital. This production and easy shipment of the drink made Hidalgo rich, and gave rise to a "pulque aristocracy" made up of some of the most powerful families of this time: Torres Adalid, Pimenta y Fagoaga, Macedo and others. At its peak, there were about 300 pulque haciendas. Some still remain in the plains of [[Apan]] and [[Zempoala, Hidalgo|Zempoala]], in Hidalgo.<ref name="lugares"/><ref name="madness"/><ref name="mexdes"/> Pulque hit its peak of popularity during the late 19th century, when it was enjoyed by rich and poor alike.<ref name="Tlaxcala"/> As late as 1953, Hidalgo and Tlaxcala still obtained 30 and 50% respectively of their total revenues from pulque. This has diminished since then since irrigation, roads and other infrastructure has made possible other, more lucrative enterprises.<ref name="barriosp38">{{cite book |last1=De Barrios |first1=Virginia B. |title=A Guide to Tequila, Mezcal and Pulque |year=2002 |publisher=Minutiae Mexicana S.A de C.V. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968-7074-46-9 |page=38 }}</ref>
===Decline=== In spite of its former popularity, pulque represents only 10% of the alcoholic beverages consumed in Mexico today.<ref name="madness"/> Pulque is still consumed in Mexico, mostly in the central highlands and predominantly in rural and poor areas. It has acquired a general connotation of being something for the lower class, while consumption of European-style beer flourished throughout the 20th century.<ref name="brewers">{{cite news |title=Brewers sought to disparage pulque |url=http://www2.eluniversal.com.mx/pls/impreso/noticia.html?id_nota=22910&tabla=miami |agency=Wire Services |newspaper=El Universal |location=Miami |date=2007-01-11 |accessdate=12 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615062222/http://www2.eluniversal.com.mx/pls/impreso/noticia.html?id_nota=22910&tabla=miami |archivedate=15 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The complex and delicate fermentation process of pulque had always limited the product's distribution, as it does not keep long and agitation during transport speeds degradation. Since pre-Hispanic times, its consumption has mostly been limited to the central highlands of Mexico.<ref name="brewers"/>
The decline of pulque began in the first decade of the 20th century, when the [[Mexican Revolution]] caused a decline in its production.<ref name="lugares"/> In the 1930s, the government of [[Lázaro Cárdenas]] campaigned against pulque, as part of an effort to reduce alcoholic consumption in general. But the most decisive factor to the decline of pulque has been the introduction of beer.<ref name="Tlaxcala"/><ref name="brewers"/>
European immigrant beer brewers in the early 20th century had their own campaign against the native pulque, claiming that pulque producers used a ''muñeca'' (doll), a textile bag containing human or animal feces which was placed in the ''aguamiel'' to hasten the fermentation process. Some pulque producers have insisted that the ''muñeca'' is completely a myth, but modern historians suggest that it did happen, although only rarely.<ref name="MacClancyHenry2009">{{cite book |author1= Jeremy M. MacClancy |author2= C.J.K. Henry |author3= Jeya Henry |author4= Helen Macbeth |title= Consuming the Inedible: Neglected Dimensions of Food Choice |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=GSKrAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA215 |year=2009 |publisher= Berghahn Books |isbn= 978-1-84545-684-9 |pages= 215–221}}</ref> Beer producers promoted the idea that pulque was generally made this way, generally by word of mouth and insinuation. This was done to inhibit pulque sales and to promote the consumption of beer, which they claimed was "rigorously hygienic and modern".<ref name="brewers"/><ref name="mentira">{{cite news |title= Mentira que se use excremento para elaborar pulque |url=http://www.elsiglodetorreon.com.mx/noticia/254842.mentira-que-se-use-excremento-para-elaborar-p.html |newspaper=El Siglo de Torreon |location=Torreon, Coahuila |date=2007-01-11 |accessdate=12 September 2009 }}</ref>
The strategy proved successful, with pulque now generally looked-down-upon and imbibed by relatively few people, with Mexican-brewed beer ubiquitous and extremely popular.<ref name="brewers"/><ref name="mentira"/> Pulque's popularity is low and continues to fall. Twenty years ago, about 20 trucks would come every three days to [[Xochimilco]] (in southern Mexico City) to deliver pulque, but now the number is down to one or two. Only five pulquerias remain in this district, where there used to be 18.<ref name="sacred"/> The situation is similar in most other parts of Mexico, as well. The remaining pulquerias are very small establishments, selling a product made by small producers.<ref name="lugares"/>
In the state of Hidalgo, in which most maguey is grown, fields of this plant are disappearing, with barley taking its place. Most maguey plants here serve as boundary markers between properties. Many of these plants do not survive long, as they are often vandalized. An estimated 10,000 plants are mutilated each week by cutting off the lower leaves for [[barbacoa]] or destroying them completely to look for the edible white grubs or ant eggs that can inhabit them.<ref name="lugares"/>
==Production== [[File:Campos de Maguey.jpg|thumb|A field of maguey]] The production process is long and delicate.<ref name="Tlaxcala"/> The maguey plant needs 12 years of maturation before the sap, or ''aguamiel'', can be extracted, but a good plant can produce for up to one year.<ref name="whatis"/> This aguamiel can be drunk straight, but it is alcoholic only after a fermentation process that can start in the plant itself.<ref name="lugares"/> This liquid is collected twice a day from the plant, yielding about five or six liters per day. Today, this liquid is collected with a steel scoop, but in the past, an elongated gourd was used as a tube to suck the juice out. Between gatherings, the plant's leaves are bent over the center where the juice collects to keep out bugs and dirt. This center is regularly scraped out to keep the plant's production of sap active. Most maguey plants produce this ''aguamiel'' for about four to six months before they finally die.<ref name="whatis"/><ref name="barrios"/> Some plants can yield up to 600 [[Litre|L]] of pulque. <!-- pp. 72 --><ref name="Tompkins" >Tompkins, P. (1976). Mysteries of the Mexican pyramids. Fitzhenry & Whiteside Limited: Toronto. {{ISBN|0-06-014324-X}}</ref>
The collected juice is placed into 50-liter barrels and carried from the field to the fermentation vats. These vats, called ''tinas'', are located in a special building called a ''tinacal''. This word derives from Spanish ''tina'' and Nahuatl ''calli'' that means house of vats. When pulque haciendas reached their peak in the late 19th century, hacienda life revolved around these ''tinacals''. It typically was a rectangular shed of stone with a wooden roof. The upper parts of the walls opened for air circulation and the façades were sometimes decorated with indigenous designs or other images associated with the making of pulque. One popular motif was the discovery of pulque by Xochitl. Other popular elements were the images of the hacienda's patron saint and the [[Virgin of Guadalupe]]. Inside were the vats, which were cowhide stretched over wooden frames lined up against the walls. In larger ''tinacals'', there were three or four rows of vats. Today, the ''tinas'' are made of oak, plastic or [[fiberglass]] and hold about 1,000 liters each.<ref name="lugares"/><ref name="barrios"/>
[[Image:1964 Tlachiquero Hidalgo Mexico.jpg|thumb|A ''tlachiquero'' collecting maguey juice (1964, Hidalgo, Mexico)]] After placing the juice in the fermentation vats, mature seed pulque (''semilla'' or ''xanaxtli'') is added to "jump start" the process. Unlike beer, the fermenting agent present in pulque is a bacterium of the species ''[[Zymomonas mobilis]]'' (syn. ''Thermobacterium mobile'' <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uniprot.org/taxonomy/542|title=Zymomonas mobilis|website=www.uniprot.org}}</ref>) rather than yeast. Those in charge of the fermentation process guard their trade secrets, passing them on from father to son. Fermentation takes from seven to 14 days, and the process seems to be more art than science. A number of factors can affect fermenting pulque, such as temperature, humidity and the quality of the ''aguamiel''.<ref name="barrios"/>
The process is complex and delicate, and can go sour at any point. For this reason, and perhaps due to its ancient "sacred" character, there are rituals and prohibitions. Religious songs and prayers may be offered, and women, children and strangers are not allowed inside the ''tinacal''.<ref name="lugares"/> Other superstitions include those against eating canned fish and wearing a hat inside the tinacal. The first is claimed to cause a bad taste in the pulque and the second is considered bad luck. To cleanse the bad luck, the offender must fill the hat with pulque and drink it down.<ref name="madness"/>
Just before the peak of fermentation, the pulque is quickly shipped to market in barrels. The fermentation process is continuous, so the pulque must be consumed within a certain time before it spoils.<ref name="madness"/>
==Consumption== [[File:Pulque donkey and vendor.jpg|thumb|Pulque donkey and vendor in [[Zacatecas City]]]] [[File:DanielVeraSierra03.JPG|thumb|left|Tending the bar at Pulquería Tecolote in Santa Marta Acatitla, Mexico City]] [[File:DanielVeraSierra05.JPG|thumb|left|Customers at Pulquería Tecolote]] Most pulque is consumed in bars called ''pulquerías''. At the beginning of the 20th century, more than 1,000 were located in Mexico City alone.<ref name="madness"/> By the early 20th century, ''pulquerías'' became socially accepted, and some were places of great elegance. But whether for rich or poor, two features stood out among these establishments: odd or catchy names, and murals decorating the walls. Names included (translated) "My Office", "Memories of the Future", "Drink and Go", "I'm Waiting for You Here at the Corner", and, across the street from the [[Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)|National Chamber of Deputies]], "The Recreation Center of Those Across the Street". [[Diego Rivera]] once said one of the most important manifestations of Mexican painting was the murals that decorated the facades and interiors of ''pulquerías''. One tradition maintained at all'' pulquerias ''at the beginning of the 20th century was to put sawdust on the floor. The tradition at that time was to begin a pulque-drinking session by spilling a little on the floor or ground as an offering to Mother Earth.<ref name="barrios2223">{{cite book |last1=De Barrios |first1=Virginia B. |title=A Guide to Tequila, Mezcal and Pulque |year=2002 |publisher=Minutiae Mexicana S.A de C.V. |location=Mexico City |isbn=968-7074-46-9 |pages=22–23 }}</ref> Traditional ''pulquerías'' tend to be like clubs with closed membership, with casual visitors ignored or sometimes stared at. Frequent visits and large consumption of the drink tends to win acceptance.<ref name="madness"/> While some establishments may forbid women,<ref name="madness"/> it is much more common for the establishment to provide a separate seating area for them. Intermingling of the sexes is not permitted.<ref name="dioses">{{cite web |author=Jorge |title= El Pulque "La Bebida de los Dioses" |url=http://www.viajaydescubre.com/articulo/el-pulque-la-bebida-de-los-dioses/ |trans-title=Pulque, the Drink of the Gods |language=Spanish |accessdate=11 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809151719/http://www.viajaydescubre.com/articulo/el-pulque-la-bebida-de-los-dioses/ |archivedate=2009-08-09}}</ref><ref name="resusitan">{{cite web |first=Virginia |last=Avila |title= Resusitan pulquerías del siglo XIX, aquí |url= http://www.e-consulta.com/oaxaca/index2.php?option=com_content&do_pdf=1&id=4719 |trans-title=Resuscitating 19th century pulque bars here |date=2008-12-18 |language=Spanish |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref><ref name="nuestro">{{cite web |title= Nuestro Pulque |url= http://pulquenuestro.blogspot.com/2009/06/10-de-algunas-cosas-que-hacen-una.html |trans-title=Our Pulque |language=Spanish |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref> In the more rural areas of Hidalgo and Tlaxcala, where most pulque is made, the pulque is fresher and better. A vendor usually displays a white flag over the door when a fresh shipment has arrived.<ref name="madness"/>
Traditionally, pulque is served from large barrels on ice.<ref name="dioses"/> and served into glasses, using a ''jicara'', which is a half of a calabash tree gourd. The bartender is called a ''jicarero''. In a ''pulquería'', ''cruzado'', meaning something like "bottoms up", is a frequent salute.<ref name="madness"/> [[File:PulqueGlasswareMAPDF.JPG|thumb|Traditional glassware for pulque ''circa'' 1950 on display at the Museo de Artes Populares, Mexico City]] Drinking glasses have colorful names and can reflect a customer's ability to drink pulque. Large two-liter glasses are called ''macetas'' (flower pots), one-liter glasses are called ''cañones'' (cannons), half–liters are called ''chivitos'' (little goats), quarter-liter glasses are ''catrinas'' (dandies), and eighth-liter glasses are ''tornillos'' (screws). Traditionally, these glasses are made from a greenish, hand blown glass.<ref name="madness"/> Pulque can be drunk straight from the barrel or can have a number of additives, such as fruit or nuts, added. Pulque prepared this way is called ''curado'' or cured.<ref name="dioses"/>
One of the limitations to pulque's popularity has been the inability to store it for long periods or ship it far. Recently, pulque makers have found a way to preserve the beverage in cans. However, they admit this does change the flavor. The hope is that with this innovation, pulque can regain its lost market in Mexico and even achieve success as an export item, like tequila.<ref name="Tlaxcala"/> It is already being offered in the United States by Boulder Imports, selling the brand "Nectar del Razo". The original market was Mexican-American men, but the company reports the product is having success as a health food, sought out by athletes and body builders.<ref name="razo">{{cite web |title= Nectar del Razo|url= http://www.pocotequila.com/mextour/mex_agave/m3pulque.html |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref>
<!--white space above was added to help format the photo layout--> [[Image:pulqueria-mexico-df.jpg|thumb|A ''pulqueria'' (pulque bar) on [[Plaza Garibaldi]] in [[Mexico City]]]]
==Health benefits== There is a saying that pulque "sólo le falta un grado para ser carne" – "it is only a bit shy of being meat", referring to the nutritional value of the drink.<ref name="resusitan"/> This was recognized by the Mesoamericans, who allowed pregnant women and the elderly to imbibe what was normally reserved only for priests and nobility. Modern analysis of the liquid has found that it contains carbohydrates, [[vitamin C]], B-complex, D, E, [[amino acid]]s and minerals such as [[iron]] and [[phosphorus]].<ref name="madness"/><ref name="Tlaxcala"/>
==Pulque tourism== From the glory days of pulque, the state of Hidalgo has about 250 pulque haciendas, many of which have been abandoned or converted to other uses, such as ranching. Their ''tinacals'' have either disappeared or been converted into storage or party rooms. A few remaining ones continue to make pulque, but use more modern and sanitary facilities.<ref name="lugares"/> In Tlaxcala, the federal [[Secretary of Tourism (Mexico)|Secretariat of Tourism]] and the state government have organized a tour called the "Pulque Route", which includes the main haciendas that still make the beverage in this state. It is a two-day route which begins at the Church of La Barca de la Fe in [[Calpulalpan]] to the San Bartolo Hacienda, which is the principal exporter of canned pulque. This hacienda was the property of Ignacio Torres Adalid, who was called the "king of pulque". Today, it belongs to Ricardo del Razo. The tour also covers maguey fields like those around a town called Guillermo Ramirez.<ref name="Tlaxcala"/> [[Image:Agave Pulque.JPG|thumb|A six pack of pulque]]
These old haciendas varied widely. Some were ostentatious with great architectural harmony such as the Montecillos Hacienda, of Spanish colonial style and originally built in the 17th century by the Jesuits or San Antonio Ometusco Hacienda built by architect Antonio Rivas Mercado. However, most haciendas were the result of a constructive process that started in the 16th century, with mixed architectural styles and methods of both Mexico and Europe. One characteristic feature is [[Neo-Gothic]] towers. The Santiago Tetlapayac Hacienda has murals related to [[charreada]] and attributed to the painter Icaza. The Zotoluca Hacienda has an octangonal floorplan in [[Neo-Moorish]] style and was restored in the 1950s. But the center of each of these pulque haciendas is the tinacal. They were planned and decorated befitting their importance. Almost all have interesting architectural details, such as a specially decorated main doorway, murals or sculpted windows. Some are considered works of art, such as the tinacal at the Montecillos Hacienda or the one at the San Antonio Ometusco Hacienda, which also has an elegant canopy covering the shipping dock with moulded iron columns and walls decorated with murals relating to the history of pulque.<ref name="lugares"/>

{{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = Religion in Haiti according to the [[Pew Research Center]] (2010)<ref>[http://www.globalreligiousfutures.org/countries/haiti#/?affiliations_religion_id=11&affiliations_year=2010&region_name=All%20Countries&restrictions_year=2015 Haiti]</ref> |label1 = [[Roman Catholicism]] |value1 = 56.8 |color1 = purple |label2 = [[Protestantism]] |value2 = 29.6 |color2 = Blue |label3 = Unaffiliated |value3 = 10.6 |color3 = gray |label4 = Other |value4 = 3 |color4 = Red }}
[[Haiti]], for much of its history and including present-day has been prevailingly a [[Christianity|Christian]] country, primarily [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]], although in some instances it is profoundly modified and influenced through [[syncretism]]. A common syncretic religion is [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]], which combined the [[West Africa]]n religions of the [[Slavery in Haiti|African slaves]] with Catholicism and some Native American strands; it shows similarities to [[Cuba]]n [[Santería]].
The largest [[Christian denomination]] in the country is [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]], which is estimated to be about 55 percent of the population according to the 2018 CIA World Factbook<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ha.html</ref>, and 57 percent according to the Pew Research Center. The historical background is very much due to the [[French colonial empire|French influence]] brought about through the newly conquered territories.
[[Protestantism in Haiti|Protestantism]] has grown in recent years and Protestants are currently estimated by the CIA World Factbook to form 28.5% of the population, while the Pew Research Center estimates their share to be nearly 30 percent.
==Christianity==
===Catholicism=== {{Main|Roman Catholicism in Haiti|Christianity in Haiti}} [[File:Cathedral of Cap-Haitien.jpg|thumb|right|Cathedral of Our Lady of the Assumption in [[Cap-Haïtien]]]] The predominant [[Christian denomination|denomination]] is [[Roman Catholicism]].<ref name="Haiti">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90257.htm |title=Haiti |publisher=State.gov |date=2007-09-14 |accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref> Similar to the rest of [[Latin America]], Saint-Domingue was built up by Roman Catholic European powers such as the [[Spanish Empire|Spanish]] and the French. Following in this legacy, Catholicism was in the Haitian constitution as its official state religion until 1987.<ref name="Haiti"/> According to recent estimates by the CIA World Factbook and Pew Research Center, between 55 and 60% of Haitians are Catholics. [[Pope John Paul II]] visited Haiti in 1983. In a speech in the capital of [[Port-au-Prince]], he criticized the government of [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]]. It is believed that the impact of this speech on the Catholic bureaucracy in Haiti contributed to his removal in 1986.
According to the Catholic Church in Haiti, the 10 dioceses of the two ecclesiastical provinces of Haiti include 251 parishes and about 1,500 Christian rural communities. The local clergy has 400 diocesan priests and 300 seminarians. There are also 1,300 religious missionary priests belonging to more than 70 religious order and fraternities. Vocations to the priesthood are plentiful.<ref>[http://ecdha.org/content/view/17/30/ Site Web Officiel de l'Eglise de Haïti - L'épiscopat] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108092709/http://ecdha.org/content/view/17/30/ |date=2009-01-08 }}</ref>
===Protestantism=== {{Main|Protestantism in Haiti}}
The CIA Factbook reports that around 28.5% of the population is Protestant (Baptist 15.4%, Pentecostal 7.9%, Adventist 3%, Methodist 1.5% other 0.7%)<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ha.html</ref>. Other sources put the Protestant population higher than this, suggesting that it may form one-third of the population today, as Protestant churches have experienced significant growth in recent decades.<ref>{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=40SIdXeUEhUC|title = Crossing the Water and Keeping the Faith: Haitian Religion in Miami|last = Rey|first = Terry|last2 = Stepick|first2 = Alex|date = 2013-08-19|publisher = NYU Press|isbn = 9781479820771|language = en}}</ref> Other sources put the Protestant population higher than this, suggesting that it might have formed form one-third of the population in 2001.<ref name="Rey & Stepick">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=40SIdXeUEhUC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Crossing the Water and Keeping the Faith: Haitian Religion in Miami |editor1=Rey, Terry |editor2=Stepick, Alex |page=5 |year=2013 |isbn=9780814777084 |accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref>
The [[Episcopal Diocese of Haiti]]<ref>[http://www.egliseepiscopaledhaiti.org/ Eglise Episcopale D'Haiti]</ref> is the Anglican Communion diocese consisting of the entire territory of Haiti. It is part of [[Province 2 of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Province 2]] of the [[Episcopal Church (United States)]]. Its cathedral, Holy Trinity (French: Cathédrale Sainte Trinité) located in the corner of Avenue Mgr. Guilloux and Rue Pavée in downtown Port-au-Prince, has been destroyed six times, including in the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]. It is the largest diocese in the [[Episcopal Church (United States)]], with 83,698 members reported in 2008.<ref>[http://www.episcopalchurch.org/documents/Statistical_Totals_for_the_Episcopal_Church_by_Province_and_Diocese_2007-2008.pdf The Episcopal Church, Baptized Members by Province & Diocese: 1998-2008]</ref>
===The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints===
Missionary work in Haiti by [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] began in May 1980<ref name="LDS Newsroom">{{cite web | url=http://www.mormonnewsroom.org/facts-and-statistics/country/haiti | title=Haiti | publisher=LDS Newsroom | accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref> and the land was dedicated for the preaching of the gospel by [[Thomas S. Monson]], then a member of the church's [[Quorum of the Twelve Apostles (LDS Church)|Quorum of the Twelve Apostles]], on 17 April 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mission.net/haiti/port-au-prince/page.php?pg_id=5263 | title=Prière de Dédicace | accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> As of 2018, the church reported having 46 congregations and more than 23,000 members in Haiti.<ref name="LDS Newsroom"/> In September 2012, the third and fourth Haitian [[Stake (Latter Day Saints)|stakes]] were created.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mission.net/haiti/port-au-prince/news.php?nID=5924 | title=Fourth Haitian Stake Organized | accessdate=2013-05-09}}</ref> All four stakes are based in the [[Port-au-Prince|capital]] region; [[District (LDS Church)|districts]] are based in [[Les Cayes]], [[Saint-Marc]], [[Gonaïves]], and [[Cap-Haïtien]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mission.net/haiti/port-au-prince/page.php?pg_id=2854 | title=Wards & Branches | accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref>
At the church's April 2009 [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]], Fouchard Pierre-Nau, a native of [[Jérémie]], was called as an [[area seventy]] in the church's [[Fourth Quorum of the Seventy]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lds.org/general-conference/2010/04/the-sustaining-of-church-officers?lang=eng | title=Sustaining of Church Officers | publisher=April 2009 General Conference Report | accessdate=2014-09-19}}</ref> the most prominent church position ever held by a Haitian. In April 2016, Pierre-Nau was released and Hubermann Bien-Aimé, a native of Gonaïves,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mission.net/haiti/port-au-prince/presidents.php?prID=8607 | title=President Hubermann Bien-Aimé | accessdate=2016-07-13}}</ref> was called to that same quorum.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lds.org/church/news/members-sustain-11-new-general-authorities | title=Members Sustain 11 New General Authorities | publisher=Church News | accessdate=2016-07-13}}</ref>
During the April 2015 General Conference, Monson—now serving as the church's [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|president]]—announced the church's intention to build a [[Port-au-Prince Haiti Temple|temple]] in Port-au-Prince.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sltrib.com/lifestyle/faith/2367124-155/monson-announces-3-new-mormon-temples | title=Monson announces 3 new Mormon temples | accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> Groundbreaking took place 28 October 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sltrib.com/religion/2017/10/29/mormon-church-breaks-ground-on-long-awaited-haiti-temple | title=Groundbreaking Held for Port-au-Prince Haiti Temple | publisher=Salt Lake Tribune | accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref> In anticipation of the temple's completion, Fritzner and Gina Joseph were called in August 2018 as the first president and matron of the temple.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lds.org/church/news/new-temple-president-called-to-serve-in-haiti | title=New Temple President Called to Serve in Haiti | publisher=Church News | accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref>
==Vodou== {{Main|Haitian Vodou}} The New World Afro-[[diasporic]] religion of Vodou is also practised. Vodou encompasses several different traditions, and consists of a mix encompassing African, European and indigenous ''[[Taíno people|Taíno]]'' religious elements. In this way, it is very similar to other Latin American [[syncretist]] movements, such as the [[Cuba]]n [[Santería]]. It is more widespread in rural parts of the country, partly due to negative [[Social stigma|stigma]]s attached to its practice. During the season of [[Lent]], Vodou societies create parading musical bands for a festival called [[Rara]], and fulfill religious obligations in local spaces such as streams, rivers, trees.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Rara! Vodou, Power, and Performance in Haiti and its Diaspora|last = McAlister|first = Elizabeth|publisher = University of California Press|year = 2002|isbn = |location = Berkeley}}</ref>
The CIA World Factbook reports that 2.1% of the population identifies its religion as Vodou, but adds that "many Haitians practice elements of Vodou in addition to another religion, most often Roman Catholicism." <ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ha.html The World Factbook]</ref> The proportion of Haitians that practice Vodou is disputed, due to the often [[syncretic]] manner in which it is practiced alongside Catholicism. Haitian Protestants are less likely to practice Vodou, as their churches strongly denounce it as diabolical.<ref name="Rey & Stepick"/>
==Islam== {{Main|Islam in Haiti}} There is a small [[Islam|Muslim]] community in Haiti, mainly residing in Port-au-Prince, Cap-Haïtien and its surrounding suburbs. The history of Islam on the island of [[Hispaniola]] (which Haiti shares with the [[Dominican Republic]]) begins with slavery in Haiti. Many Muslims were imported as slaves to Haiti{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}}.
In 2000, [[Nawoon Marcellus]], a member of [[Fanmi Lavalas]] from [[Saint-Raphaël, Haiti|Saint-Raphaël]], became the first Muslim elected to the [[Chamber of Deputies (Haiti)|Chamber of Deputies of Haiti]].
==Bahá'í Faith== {{Main|Bahá'í Faith in Haiti}} The [[Bahá'í Faith]] in Haiti begins with a mention by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, in 1916 as one of the island countries of the Caribbean being among the places Bahá'ís should take the religion to.<ref name="sohrab">{{cite book | last = Abbas | first = `Abdu'l-Bahá |author2=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab |author3=trans. and comments | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}</ref> The first Bahá'í to visit Haiti was [[Leonora Armstrong]] in 1927.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bahai-library.com/books/bw18/720-748.html |title=In Memoriam |authors=Universal House of Justice |journal=The Bahá'í World |volume= XVIII |publisher= Bahá'í World Centre |pages= 733–738 |year= 1986 |isbn= 0-85398-234-1 |accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref> After that others visited until [[Louis George Gregory]] visited in January 1937 and he mentions a small community of Bahá'ís operating in Haiti.<ref name="BN109">{{cite magazine | title = Annual Report Inter-America Committee |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1937 | number = 109 |pages=3–5 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}}</ref> The first long term [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]], Ruth and Ellsworth Blackwell, arrived in 1940.<ref name="BN139">{{cite magazine | title = InterAmerica Teaching|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1940 | number = 139 | page =4 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}}</ref> Following their arrival the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of [[Haiti]] was formed in 1942 in [[Port-au-Prince]].<ref name="BN154">{{cite magazine | title = Supplement to Annual Report of the National Spiritual Assembly 1941-42 |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1942 | number = 154 |pages=11–12 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}}</ref> From 1951 the Haitian Bahá'ís participated in regional organizations of the religion<ref name="BN247">{{cite magazine | title = Central America, Mexico and the Antilles |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1951 | number = 247 |pages=9–10 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}}</ref> until 1961 when Haitian Bahá'ís elected their own [[National Spiritual Assembly]]<ref name="notes">{{Citation | title = National Spiritual Assemblies Statistics | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | accessdate = 2008-11-27}}</ref> and soon took on goals reaching out into neighboring islands.<ref name="BN411">{{cite magazine | title = Teaching Conference Held in Honduras |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1965 | number = 411 | page =1 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}}</ref> The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying mostly on the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 21,000 Bahá'ís in Haiti in 2005.<ref name="WCE-05">{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | doi = | accessdate = 2010-01-30}}</ref>
==Judaism== {{Main|History of the Jews in Haiti}}
Sephardic Jews arrived in [[Saint-Domingue]] during the first days of the colonial period, despite that they were banned in the official Catholic edicts. They became merchants and integrated themselves into the French Catholic society. Waves of Jews continued to immigrate to the Haiti, including a group of [[Ashkenazi Jews]] escaping Hitler's Germany in the 1940s; Haiti was one of the few countries to welcome them openly. Haitian Catholics had idiosyncratic ideas about Jews, stemming from Catholic anti-Judaism, although many Vodou practitioners imagined themselves to be the descendants of Jews and to hold esoteric Judaic knowledge.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Jew in the Haitian Imagination|last = McAlister|first = Elizabeth|publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 2004|isbn = 0195149181|location = New York|pages = 61–84|work = Race, Nation, and Religion in the Americas|editor-last = Goldschmidt|editor-first = Henry|editor-last2 = McAlister|editor-first2 = Elizabeth}}</ref>
There is a group of [[Jews|Judaism]] predominantly residing in Port-au-Prince, where the community today meets at the home of businessman billionaire [[Gilbert Bigio]], a Haitian of [[Syria]]n descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://warincontext.org/2010/01/25/does-gilbert-bigio-make-israel-look-good/ |title=Does Gilbert Bigio make Israel look good? |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> Bigio's father first settled in Haiti in 1925 and was active in the Jewish community. In November 1947, his father played a significant role in Haiti's support for the statehood of Israel in a vote to the United Nations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slowlygetrich.com/haiti-richest-man-billionaire-gilbert-bigio/ |title=Haiti richest Man, Billionaire Gilbert Bigio |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> Every [[Rosh Hashanah]] and [[Yom Kippur]], services are held at his residence. The last Jewish wedding to take place in Haiti occurred 10 years ago; Bigio’s daughter, while the last [[bris]] was done for his son, more than 30 years ago. Bigio owns the only [[Torah]] in all of the country, which he provides to the community for services.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/haiti.html The Virtual Jewish World: Haiti]</ref>
